column1: 169	Carel	Barack Obama	Individual	https://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/19/politics/stock-act-loophole/index.html	"(CNN) —
It was a rare show of bipartisanship – President Barack Obama
column2: flanked by Democrats and Republicans in April
column3: signing into law a bill that would ban insider trading on Capitol Hill. The measure
column4: known as the STOCK Act
column5: had passed the House and Senate at warp speed.

column1: “The powerful shouldn’t get to create one set of rules for themselves and another set of rules for everybody else
column2: ” the president said at the time.

column1: Lawmakers proclaimed that the bill
column2: officially called the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge Act
column3: would restore trust in government. It also applied new rules to some employees of the executive branch.

column1: GSA: $250K spent on one-day event

But CNN uncovered that the law that members of Congress thought they voted for earlier this year isn’t exactly as advertised. A loophole could still allow family members of some lawmakers to profit from inside information.
The STOCK Act requires that any trades of $1
column2: 000 or more made on or after July 3 have to be reported to the House and Senate within 45 days. But the House and Senate have two completely different interpretations of that rule.

column1: In the Senate
column2: the Ethics Committee released one page of guidelines last month ruling that members and their spouses and dependent children all have to file reports after they make stock or securities trades. But the House Ethics Committee disagreed.

column1: Its 14-page memo notifies House members and aides covered by the law that their spouses and children aren’t covered. The Office of Government Ethics
column2: which oversees all federal executive branch employees
column3: sided with the House
column4: informing its employees that their spouses and children don’t need to file these periodic reports.

column1: Both of the lead sponsors of the Senate bill didn’t realize the discrepancy until CNN brought it to their attention.
Massachusetts Republican Scott Brown
column2: the only Republican senator to attend the White House signing ceremony
column3: said he was “obviously very concerned.”

column1: “Say I find out some information
column2: I tell my wife and she goes and trades on it
column3: what’s the difference?” Brown told CNN.

column1: Brown
column2: who speaks constantly about this bill in his neck-and-neck race for re-election against consumer advocate Elizabeth Warren
column3: said the whole point of passing the law was to demonstrate that members of Congress weren’t held to a different standard.

column1: “I mean
column2: bottom line
column3: we’re supposed to have that level of transparency and have us be treated like every other member of the United States and bottom line
column4: if we can’t do it
column5: then – sorry
column6: if they can’t do it – then we shouldn’t be able to do it as well.”

column1: Why won’t Romney release more tax documents?
Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand
column2: D-New York
column3: also criticized the House decision not to include congressional spouses and children.

column1: “I think it’s wrong
column2: and I think it’s unfortunate because the reality is the whole point of this legislation is we should play by the exact same rules as every other American citizen
column3: and when all of America looks at Washington
column4: they know it’s broken.”

column1: “We’re trying to restore just a small measure of confidence through this kind of transparency and accountability
column2: ” Gillibrand said.

column1: After CNN told Brown about the House interpretation
column2: Brown fired off a letter to his GOP colleagues in the House
column3: Speaker John Boehner and House Majority Leader Eric Cantor.

column1: “The House interpretation leaves a loophole and the appearance of an ongoing double standard
column2: ” Brown said in the letter.

column1: “It is deeply troubling that the House of Representatives and Executive Branch would attempt to operate under a substantially weaker interpretation than the Senate
column2: ” he added
column3: demanding that the House adopt the Senate’s view and require all spouses and dependents to begin reporting stock trades.

column1: Chances for an Anthony Weiner comeback
Why the difference?
Robert Walker
column2: a Washington ethics attorney and former chief counsel for both the House and Senate Ethics Committees
column3: explained that the Senate bill did include a provision that covered spouses and children
column4: but when Cantor’s office wrote the House version
column5: this language was shifted to a different section of the bill. The change meant that spouses and dependent children weren’t subject to the new reporting requirements.

column1: “The House recrafted some of the provisions of it and moved some of the provisions around. In that process
column2: some of the Senate bill that applied to filing of these new reports was moved from one section of the bill to the other
column3: ” Walker said.

column1: The Senate Ethics Committee decided to stick with the spirit of the law that senators originally intended
column2: but the House Ethics Committee went with the letter of the law
column3: which included the loophole not requiring spouses and children to report financial transactions in a timely fashion.

column1: GOP senators block Obama job initiative
Why does it matter?
This so-called “loophole” goes to the heart of what the STOCK Act set out to do.
While there were already laws in place barring members of Congress or the executive branch from profiting from nonpublic information that they learn in the course of their duties
column2: it was extremely difficult for those at the Securities and Exchange Commission to enforce those laws.

column1: The financial disclosure forms House members and senators were already required to file only come out once a year
column2: making it tough to track any relationship between legislative action and a stock trade. That’s why the STOCK Act added the rule that after each trade over $1
column3: 000 a report had to be filed in a timely manner.

column1: Walker stressed the new law provides “more immediacy
column2: more real time so that the public could have more real-time understanding of what their members
column3: of their senior staff and other high government officials were doing with their finances

By Marcin Goclowski

WARSAW
column34: May 26 (Reuters) - Polish prosecutors have started an investigation into suspected money laundering at a small state-controlled lender BOS Bank
column35: Dziennik Gazeta Prawna daily said on Tuesday
column36:
quoting an unnamed source.

The regional prosecutor’s office in Katowice in southern Poland said in an emailed statement to Reuters: “An investigation has been initiated in the local prosecutor’s office regarding irregularities in connection with transactions carried out on bank accounts for selected foreign entities at one of the banks.” The prosecutor’s office did not give further details.

BOS Bank said in a statement on Tuesday that it complies with all anti-money laundering regulations and cooperates with authorities. A BOS Bank spokeswoman declined to comment further.

A spokesman for Poland’s financial sector regulator KNF declined to comment.

BOS Bank shares were down 1.1% by 1213 GMT
column37:
underperforming the Polish stock market’s banking index which was up 2.9%

column38:
but money laundering is rarely a part of public debate.

Poland ranks at 102 out of 125 in a 2019 ranking of countries with highest risk of money laundering compiled by the Basel Institute of Governance. Poland’s ranking indicates that the risk of money laundering in the country is relatively low.

Preventing money laundering has become an increasing focus for regulators in Europe after Estonia became the centre of a major money-laundering scandal in 2017.

The European Union is looking at how to strengthen its scrutiny of the financial sector after a spate of scandals in Estonia

column58: amongst other things
column59: preferring the tenders submitted by the Companies (even though they were not the lowest)
column60: tweaking AMKTC’s tender requirements to suit the Companies’ specifications
column61:
and providing input and advice to Chia on the Companies’ bid pricing and technical information.

At trial
column62:
both Wong and Chia pleaded guilty to three charges of participating in public sector corruption with an agent under s 6 read with s 7 of the PCA. The Public Prosecutor appealed on the basis that the sentences imposed by the District Judge were inadequate. Wong and Chia cross-appealed on the basis that the sentences imposed were excessive.

Issues

As a common law jurisdiction
column63:
the general approach towards sentencing in Singapore has always been to have regard to past cases which have identified a number of categories and factors pertinent to the sentencing process.

However
column64: in respect of corruption cases
column65:
past decisions have tended to be of limited relevance given the Public Prosecutor’s discretion to bring charges for the basic corruption offences (under ss 5 and 6 of the PCA) even if the facts could warrant invoking the enhanced punishment provisions (under s 7 of the PCA). This has created two issues for the Singapore courts:

  1. precedents tend to be of limited use; and
  2. even where the facts of previous cases are similar
column66:
a high degree of caution is still required as the sentences imposed in those cases may have been under the basic corruption offences.

In the circumstances
column67:
a sentencing framework for public sector corruption is warranted so as to provide a consistent and coherent methodology for the courts when dealing with such offences going forward.

The sentencing framework

1. Identify the level of harm caused by the offence and level of culpability
column68: having regard to the list of offence-specific factors. Accordingly
column69:
both the level of harm and level of culpability can be broadly classified into three categories scaled according to severity.

Offence-specific factors*
Factors going towards harm

Actual loss caused to principal

Benefit to the giver of gratification

Type and extent of loss to third parties

Public disquiet

Offences committed as part of a group or syndicate

Involvement of a transnational element

Factors going towards culpability

Amount of gratification given or received

Degree of planning and premeditation

Level of sophistication

Duration of offending

Extent of the offender’s abuse of position and breach of trust

Offender’s motive in committing the offence

* These are non-exhaustive factors

2. Identify the applicable indicative starting range that would apply based on the level of harm and level of culpability determined in Step 1
column70:
and the following sentencing matrix:

Harm

Culpability

SlightModerateSevere
LowFine or up to 1 year’s imprisonment1 to 2 year’s imprisonment2 to 3 years’ imprisonment
Medium1 to 2 year’s imprisonment2 to 3 years’ imprisonment3 to 4.5 years’ imprisonment
High2 to 3 years’ imprisonment3 to 4.5 years’ imprisonment4.5 to 7 years’ imprisonment

\xa0

3. Identify the appropriate indicative starting point within the sentencing range that had been chosen. This entails an examination of the offence-specific factors. This is also where the sentencing court should have regard to the public service rationale
column71:
which will typically attract a custodial sentence save for exceptional cases.

4. Make adjustments to the indicative starting point to account for offender-specific factors.

Offender-specific factors*
Aggravating factors

Offences taken into consideration for sentencing purposes

Relevant antecedents

Evident lack of remorse

Mitigating factors

A guilty plea

Co-operation with the authorities

Actions taken to minimise harm to victims

* These are non-exhaustive factors

5. Take into account the totality principle and make final adjustments to the sentence.

In brief

In a recent appeal before the Honourable Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon involving two individuals who had participated in public sector corruption (Public Prosecutor v Wong Chee Meng and another appeal\xa0[2020] SGHC 144)
column74:
the High Court set out a new sentencing framework for corrupt transactions which take place in relation to contracts with the Government or public bodies under s 6 read with s 7 of the Prevention of Corruption Act (Cap 241) (the PCA).

Key takeaways

  • Public sector corruption (i.e. which relates to the Government or public bodies) is considered an aggravated form of corruption in Singapore because it undermines the integrity of the Government
column75: and erodes the public’s trust and confidence in the various organs and bodies of the State. Given Singapore’s zero-tolerance approach to corruption
column76:
custodial sentences are presumptively the norm in cases involving public sector corruption.
  • The new sentencing framework pertains only to public sector corruption involving agents. The High Court declined to extend the new sentencing framework to cover all corruption offences under ss 5 and 6 of the PCA generally.
  • The new sentencing framework adopts a five-step analysis (please see below).

    • In more detail

    Background

    Wong was the general manager of the Ang Mo Kio Town Council (AMKTC) at the material time
column77: and was in charge of AMKTC’s operations
column78:

column1: As of March 2014

column1: Part of the reason the Koch brothers can spend vast amounts of money but still remain largely unknown public figures is because the Libertarians work to lower personal and corporate taxes

column1: “The Kochs are on a whole different level. There’s no one else who has spent this much money

column6: and obfuscation. I’ve been in Washington since Watergate

column1: Puppetmasters

The Koch brothers initiated their influence on U.S. politics by forming and funding think tanks such as the first-ever Libertarian think tank the Cato Institute and electing those who shared their political ideology to local-level positions such as school boards. In recent years
column2: though
column3: the oil barons have used their wealth to influence public policy on a national level.

column1: For example
column2: in the 2000 presidential election campaign
column3: Koch Industries reportedly spent around $900
column4: 000 to support George W. Bush and other Republicans. In 2004
column5: the Koch brothers-founded group Citizens for a Sound Economy’s Oregon chapter was accused of working to get Ralph Nader on the presidential ballot
column6: in a bid to weaken Democratic support for John Kerry and ensure a re-election for the Bush-Cheney White House.

column1: After Bush was ultimately re-elected
column2: Koch Industries and other fossil fuel companies enjoyed tremendous kickbacks such as the 2005 energy bill
column3: which Hillary Clinton referred to as “the Dick Cheney lobbyist energy bill
column4: ” since it provided enormous subsidies and tax breaks to U.S. energy companies.

column1: The Koch brothers also helped Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker
column2: who has been called a test-case and puppet of the Koch brothers

column1: As they push to take over the Senate and the White House
column2: some Democrats like Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) are coming forward and asking their colleagues to not let the Koch brothers buy their votes in order to preserve and protect democracy.

column1: “The truth is

column3: ” Reid said on the Senate floor in early March. “These two multi-billionaires may spend hundreds of millions of dollars rigging the political process for their own benefit. And they may believe that whoever has the most money gets the most free speech. But I will do whatever it takes to expose their campaign to rig the American political system to benefit the wealthy at the expense of the middle class.

column1: “Republicans are willing to defend the Koch brothers on the floor of the United States Senate. But are they willing to defend the Koch brothers’ radical policy agenda as well? If Republicans don’t support the Koch brothers’ survival of the richest philosophy
column2: all they have to do is say so
column3: ” Reid said.

column1: As the Koch brothers have more than enough money to fund an election campaign
column2: some have wondered why they don’t run for office instead of buying and influencing lawmakers on Capitol Hill and in all 50 states. In fact

column4: ” the experience changed the way the duo looked at politicians. The Koch brothers saw them not as lawmakers
column5: but merely as “actors playing out a script

column1: How they planned to influence public policy was going to be where policy ideas originate: academia and think tanks.
Abuse of wealth
Though there are several other wealthy individuals in the U.S. who found and fund private organizations
column2: higher education institutions and super PACs
column3: the difference between the Koch brothers and Democratic supporter George Soros

column6: raising concerns about the true intent of the Koch brothers’ donations.

column1: Even David Koch has admitted that the family “exerts tight ideological control” over its interests.

column2: we’ll make darn sure they spend it in a way that goes along with our intent

column1: But since the spokespersons for about 45 public and private universities who receive funding from the Koch brothers have continued to deny that the Koch brothers manipulate the curriculum
column2: the Koch brothers’ influence on academia continues to occur without alarming the American public.

column1: Even groups such as Americans for Prosperity are “micromanaged by the Kochs.” That tight control seems to have paid off for the brothers

column3: the president’s public support has dropped to historic lows and his Democratic colleagues have been unseated by Republicans
column4: some of whom are increasingly aligning with Libertarian views.

column1: As the 2014 election season heats up and radical

column1: Since the Koch brothers have been successful in manipulating the American political system for a number of decades
column2: even though they hide in the shadows

As the Koch brothers have more than enough money to fund an election campaign
column151: some have wondered why they don’t run for office instead of buying and influencing lawmakers on Capitol Hill and in all 50 states. In fact
column152:
Charles did convince David to run for office in 1979 as the vice-presidential candidate for the Libertarian Party against Republican candidate Ronald Reagan.

\n

David Koch may have lost the election
column153: but according to Brian Doherty
column154: an editor of the Libertarian magazine Reason and the author of “Radicals for Capitalism
column155: ” the experience changed the way the duo looked at politicians. The Koch brothers saw them not as lawmakers
column156: but merely as “actors playing out a script
column157:
” and reportedly said they wanted to “supply the themes and words for the scripts.”

How they planned to influence public policy was going to be where policy ideas originate: academia and think tanks.

\xa0

Abuse of wealth

Though there are several other wealthy individuals in the U.S. who found and fund private organizations
column158: higher education institutions and super PACs
column159: the difference between the Koch brothers and Democratic supporter George Soros
column160: or even Republican supporter Sheldon Adelson
column161: is that the brothers are abusing their wealth to push their self-described radical ideologies that value profit over all else. Donations made by Soros and Adelson are also much less significant than those made by the Koch brothers
column162:
raising concerns about the true intent of the Koch brothers’ donations.

\n

Even David Koch has admitted that the family “exerts tight ideological control” over its interests.

\n

“If we’re going to give a lot of money
column163: we’ll make darn sure they spend it in a way that goes along with our intent
column164: ” he told Doherty. “And if they make a wrong turn and start doing things we don’t agree with
column165:
we withdraw funding.”

\n

But since the spokespersons for about 45 public and private universities who receive funding from the Koch brothers have continued to deny that the Koch brothers manipulate the curriculum
column166:
the Koch brothers’ influence on academia continues to occur without alarming the American public.

\n

Even groups such as Americans for Prosperity are “micromanaged by the Kochs.” That tight control seems to have paid off for the brothers
column167: since during the Obama administration
column168: the president’s public support has dropped to historic lows and his Democratic colleagues have been unseated by Republicans
column169:
some of whom are increasingly aligning with Libertarian views.

\n

As the 2014 election season heats up and radical
column170: anti-democratic ideology such as voter ID laws makes its way back into the political realm
column171: the only thing the American public can be sure of is that the Koch brothers are not only funding smear campaigns against politicians whose political ideologies do not help their bottom line
column172: but they are also funding the campaigns of Republican politicians who are pro-big-oil
column173:
pro-Wall Street and pro-segregation.

\n

Since the Koch brothers have been successful in manipulating the American political system for a number of decades
column174: even though they hide in the shadows
column175:
it’s more important than ever to look at who is funding the think tanks and higher education institutions the media enlists this election season to explain the policies that are at the center of the political debate and will ultimately affect us all.

\n

If we fail to pay attention now
column176:
it’s evident from the Koch brothers’ record that only a few of us will continue to be allowed to actively participate in our democracy.

\xa0

\n\n

Robert Greenwald
column185: filmmaker and founder of Brave New Films
column186: recently announced a sequel to his 2012 film “Koch Brothers Exposed.” He said the new film will focus specifically on the duo’s efforts to buy the 2014 election
column187:
as well as how detrimental their support for Citizens United has been to the state of democracy in the United States.

\n\n

While Charles and David Koch remain largely unknown figures to the majority of the American public
column188: with 52 percent recently reporting they have never heard of them
column189:
the reality is that the brothers are arguably the most powerful and influential people in Washington — and they’ve never even been elected to office.

\n\n

Americans may not recognize the men
column190: but they’re probably familiar with the brothers’ business
column191: Koch Industries
column192: and its oil refineries in Alaska
column193: Texas and Minnesota
column194: as well as its products such as Brawny paper towels
column195: Dixie cups
column196: Georgia-Pacific lumber
column197: Stainmaster carpet and Lycra
column198:
among others.





Recognizable businesses and brands aside
column199: the public is largely unaware that the Koch brothers are doing everything they can to suppress voter rights
column200: re-segregate public schools
column201:
weaken Environmental Protection Agency regulations and privatize Social Security.

\n\n

As of March 2014
column202: the duo
column203: who are among the richest men in America
column204:
have spent at least $30 million this election season to prevent Senate Democrats from being re-elected.

\n\n

Part of the reason the Koch brothers can spend vast amounts of money but still remain largely unknown public figures is because the Libertarians work to lower personal and corporate taxes
column205: remove social services and limit oversight for industries
column207:
through think tanks and generic-sounding advocacy groups such as Americans for Prosperity.

“The Kochs are on a whole different level. There’s no one else who has spent this much money
column208: ” said Charles Lewis
column209: the founder of the Center for Public Integrity
column210: a nonpartisan watchdog group. “The sheer dimension of it is what sets them apart. They have a pattern of lawbreaking
column211: political manipulation
column212: and obfuscation. I’ve been in Washington since Watergate
column213:
and I’ve never seen anything like it. They are the Standard Oil of our times.”

column215:
the oil barons have used their wealth to influence public policy on a national level.

\n\n

For example
column216: in the 2000 presidential election campaign
column217: Koch Industries reportedly spent around $900
column218: 000 to support George W. Bush and other Republicans. In 2004
column219: the Koch brothers-founded group Citizens for a Sound Economy’s Oregon chapter was accused of working to get Ralph Nader on the presidential ballot
column220:
in a bid to weaken Democratic support for John Kerry and ensure a re-election for the Bush-Cheney White House.

\n\n

After Bush was ultimately re-elected
column221: Koch Industries and other fossil fuel companies enjoyed tremendous kickbacks such as the 2005 energy bill
column222: which Hillary Clinton referred to as “the Dick Cheney lobbyist energy bill
column223:
” since it provided enormous subsidies and tax breaks to U.S. energy companies.

The Koch brothers also helped Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker
column224: who has been called a test-case and puppet of the Koch brothers
column225: take down unions and their fight for a reasonable wage and collective bargaining
column226:

“The truth is

column229:
” Reid said on the Senate floor in early March. “These two multi-billionaires may spend hundreds of millions of dollars rigging the political process for their own benefit. And they may believe that whoever has the most money gets the most free speech. But I will do whatever it takes to expose their campaign to rig the American political system to benefit the wealthy at the expense of the middle class.

“Republicans are willing to defend the Koch brothers on the floor of the United States Senate. But are they willing to defend the Koch brothers’ radical policy agenda as well? If Republicans don’t support the Koch brothers’ survival of the richest philosophy

New data tampering scandal hits Japan

Published
28 November 2017

A subsidiary of Japanese synthetic fibre-maker Toray falsified product data
column54:
the company has admitted.

It is the latest in a series of Japanese corporate scandals in which major corporations have admitted to lapses in quality control.

Toray Hybrid Cord re-wrote quality tests before shipping products to 13 companies
column55:
including tyre makers and car parts makers.

Shares in Toray fell 8% on the news before recovering slightly.

Recurring theme

Toray is the latest in a string of Japanese companies that have admitted to lapses in quality control.

In October

Kobe Steel said it falsified strength and quality data for products shipped to hundreds of clients.

  • Nissan cuts operating profit forecast after Japan recall

column57:
000 vehicles for similar reasons.

Last week
column58:
Mitsubishi Material also admitted that its subsidiaries falsified product data.

\'Deeply apologise\'

In Tokyo on Tuesday

column60:
a gesture of contrition common at press conferences for Japanese companies affected by scandal.

""We deeply apologise for causing troubles and concerns
column61:
he said.

column62:

column63:
and after it leaked online.

column64:
he said.

column1: 422	Sebastien	Andrade Gutierrez	Organization	https://www.riskadvisory.com/news/brazilian-infrastructure-and-corruption/	Four years ago
column2: Rio de Janeiro made history by becoming the first city in South America to win a bid to host the Summer Olympics
column3: to be held in 2016. Two years earlier
column4: and to even more fanfare
column5: Brazil won the bid to host the 2014 FIFA World Cup
column6: the first to be held in South America since 1978. These accomplishments were seen as a sign of Brazil’s growing economic and political importance on the world stage. At the time
column7: then-president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva told reporters
column8: ‘I’ve never felt more pride in Brazil. Now
column9: we are going to show the world we can be a great country.’ However
column10: the attention surrounding the two sporting events has also shone a light on two major shortcomings that anyone who lives or works in Brazil is painfully aware of: infrastructure and corruption. Expanding infrastructure The World Cup and Olympics will attract a flood of both domestic and international visitors (3.6 million to the World Cup
column11: according to FIFA). These visitors will arrive in and depart from Brazil’s major airports
column12: ride its metro systems and take its buses to attend games at its stadiums. Unfortunately
column13: at present
column14: Brazil’s airports are old and running at capacity. Taking a bus in Rio de Janeiro or São Paulo can involve sitting in traffic for hours on end. Furthermore
column15: Brazil’s infrastructure requirements go much further than a need to ferry spectators and athletes to and from sporting events. The highways
column16: railroads and ports that transport the commodities that power Brazil’s economic growth are also inadequate and overwhelmed. The challenge to update Brazil’s infrastructure was clear when it won the bids to host the Olympics and the World Cup
column17: and the government has responded in kind. Over the past six years
column18: it has poured billions of dollars into upgrading infrastructure. The government’s own projections state that overall infrastructure investment reached $100 billion in 2012 and will more than double over the coming years. New investments announced last year under the Growth Acceleration Program of Investment (PAC)
column19: a government plan for infrastructure investment started under the last presidential administration
column20: will include the construction of 6
column21: 000 miles of new railways and 4
column22: 500 miles of new roads in the coming years. Corruption and infrastructure Against this backdrop
column23: the potential rewards for companies in the construction
column24: engineering and infrastructure sectors are clear. Unfortunately
column25: the large sums being spent and the involvement of government officials and entities create a fertile breeding ground for corruption. As in many developing countries
column26: corruption and infrastructure investment go hand in hand in Brazil. A 2011 study by Professor Marcos Fernandes da Silva at the Fundação Getúlio Vargas
column27: a renowned Brazilian university
column28: found that Brazil had lost R$40 billion (approximately $18 billion) to corruption between 2002 and 2008	 much of this loss was attributed to the infrastructure sector. Another study by FIESP
column29: a São Paulo-based industrial association
column30: estimated that with the money lost to corruption in the first stage of the PAC (between 2007 and 2010) 124 percent more roads and 525 percent more railways could have been built. In keeping with the scale of the problem
column31: several of Brazil’s largest corruption scandals involving the private sector have been connected to the infrastructure industry. Almost every major Brazilian construction and engineering company – including the top four
column32: Andrade Gutierrez
column33: Camargo Corrêa
column34: Odebrecht and Queiroz Galvão – has been accused of
column35: or investigated for
column36: some sort of irregularity in connection to a government tender. Smaller firms have also been implicated in corruption schemes. One of the more prominent corruption scandals of the 2000s involved a construction company called Construtora Gautama
column37: which
column38: despite having signed various construction contracts with local governments in north-eastern Brazil
column39: did not have a single engineer on its payroll. Six years later
column40: Gautama’s owner
column41: Zuleido Veras
column42: along with an ex-governor of Alagoas
column43: was convicted in an Alagoas court of diverting funds from an urban drainage project. However
column44: a larger related federal case has only just been opened. Such incidents
column45: though
column46: seldom lead to prison time. The Brazilian justice system is notoriously slow and lawyers can easily draw out a judgement for years
column47: often past the statute of limitations. Matthew Taylor
column48: a professor at American University specializing in corruption in Brazil
column49: explained to us that delays in the courts make it difficult to remove corrupt players in an efficient way. As a result
column50: unethical companies and government officials are rarely punished for engaging in corrupt practices. The corruption playbook Most corruption in the Brazilian infrastructure sector takes place between private construction and engineering companies and the government officials who contract them to carry out infrastructure projects. Governmental authorities are meant to hold tenders to choose
column51: among qualified bidders
column52: the company that can provide its services at the lowest cost. However
column53: companies can circumvent this requirement by paying the officials bribes in exchange for favourable treatment in the tender. In a recent textbook case
column54: Brazil’s Comptroller General found that Delta Construções
column55: a construction company based in Rio de Janeiro
column56: had showered state employees responsible for approving highway contracts in Ceará state in northern Brazil with gifts such as airline tickets
column57: hotel stays
column58: car rentals
column59: meals and fuel. Delta was subsequently blacklisted from government contracts and dropped out of the consortium participating in the renovation of Rio de Janeiro’s iconic Maracanã football stadium. Companies also pay bribes so that government officials will turn a blind eye to violations of tender rules though in many cases only the tender violations come to light. For example
column60: in one case
column61: Brazil’s public prosecutor’s office filed charges against several of Brazil’s largest construction companies including Andrade Gutierrez
column62: Camargo Corrêa
column63: Mendes Júnior
column64: OAS
column65: and Queiroz Galvão
column66: accusing them of rigging a R$4 billion (more than $2.34 billion at the time) tender for expansion of a subway line in São Paulo. The Folha de São Paulo
column67: a major Brazilian newspaper
column68: had reportedly obtained the results of the tender a few days before it was suspended in April 2010. The São Paulo Metro had the participants re-submit their bids
column69: supposedly due to price issues. Six months later it announced results identical to those reported by the Folha de São Paulo
column70: sparking suspicions that the winners had been agreed upon among the competing companies before the tender. While Brazil’s competition authority ruled that they had not formed a cartel
column71: the companies remain defendants in a related civil case in São Paulo. Some commentators have questioned the political donations made by large construction companies
column72: as well as their political links. For example
column73: Delta’s owner
column74: Fernando Cavendish
column75: is reported to be a close friend of the governor of Rio de Janeiro state
column76: Sérgio Cabral. Furthermore
column77: according to the local media
column78: six of the top 10 corporate political contributors are in the construction business: Andrade Gutierrez
column79: OAS
column80: Queiroz Galvão
column81: Cristiani-Nielsen
column82: Odebrecht
column83: Carvalho Hoskent and Camargo Corrêa. A study by academics from Boston University and the University of California found that government contractors received R$8.50 for every real donated to candidates from the ruling Workers’ Party elected to the Chamber of Deputies in 2006
column84: ‘although total return on investment might well be higher over the [candidate’s] full four-year term’. While these donations are all legal (and it is not a crime to be friends with a governor)
column85: some commentators have questioned the ethics of such a close relationship between construction companies and the government that gives them so much of their work. A changing tide? Although corruption is a recognised part of life for many Brazilians
column86: recent protests across the country have highlighted a growing discontent with the current state of affairs. Protests began in June in Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo
column87: ostensibly in reaction to an increase in public transportation fares. The unrest quickly escalated
column88: though
column89: with members of an increasingly large and vocal middle class calling for a change in government priorities. Desirous of a national government that addresses social
column90: as much as economic
column91: development
column92: many protesters questioned the government’s investment in stadiums when education and health systems are still wanting. Many protestors were pictured in the media carrying placards in English urging visitors not to attend the World Cup. In an effort to help quell the unrest
column93: Brazil’s president recently signed into law a long-delayed anti-corruption bill (it was first introduced in 2010)
column94: which is expected to come into force in early 2014. The new law introduces
column95: for the first time
column96: corporate liability into Brazilian anti-corruption law and addresses offenses committed by Brazilian companies outside the country. It is not clear what effect this new law will have. Corruption does not thrive in Brazil because there are no laws to address it but
column97: rather
column98: because the country’s institutions are unable or unwilling to enforce them. It is not clear at this stage
column99: for example
column100: which Brazilian federal and state agencies will take the lead in enforcing the new law. What the law does do
column101: however
column102: is underline the need for companies from jurisdictions with more robust anti-corruption enforcement to undertake proper due diligence before entering the Brazilian market. Companies that wish to operate in Brazil’s infrastructure sector and to partner with local companies need to understand who their partners are – including their reputation and political connections. If Brazil is to capitalise fully on the opportunities afforded it by hosting two of the biggest international sporting events in the next three years
column103: and if it wishes to continue down its promising development path
column104: it must ensure that its infrastructure investments are not tainted by the corrupt practices of the past. By Funmi Ojo and Allison Everhardt Business Intelligence

\n\n

Insurtech INSHUR
column183: which raised $7m in February
column184: has today announced four key appointments to help protect its customers from insurance fraud
column185:
in a bid to help keep premiums down.

\n\n

Recent data released by the ABI shows that in 2016 and 2017 there were a total of 238
column186: 000 fraudulent claims detected by UK Insurers at a cost of £1.3 billion a year. Changes in the law regarding whiplash claims
column187: through to fundamental dishonesty
column188:
have given insurers more tools to tackle fraudsters.

\n\n

For many traditional
column189: non-digital insurers
column190: this remains a perennial problem
column191:
pushing up premiums and clogging the court system.\xa0 It’s a problem INSHUR aims to reduce with its data-driven technology team.

\n\n

In order to ensure the insurtech continues to enhance protection for its customers due to fraud
column192: INSHUR has made four key hires; Mike Connolly as Head of Counter Fraud
column193: Peter Truong as Senior Business Intelligence Developer
column194: Milan Chavda as Head of Pricing
column195:
and John King as Head of Product.

\n\n

Co-founder of INSHUR
column196: David Daiches
column197: said: “Data and security have always been at the heart of what we do to ensure our customers’ needs and safety is front of mind. In order to offer insurance for commercial drivers in just three minutes
column198: compared to hours or even days
column199: we created a platform that can tap into various data sources to quickly validate a driver
column200:
verify their driving history and provide an informed risk profile.

\n\n

We’re excited to bring specialist and skilled professionals on board to ensure as we continue to grow we focus on combatting fraud
column201:
and therefore keep premiums down for our customers.”

\n\n

Mike Connolly has 17 years’ insurance experience having worked in developing counter fraud strategies and systems at Hastings Direct
column202:
Westminster Insurance and Haven Claims.

\n\n

Mike Connolly
column203: Head of Counter Fraud
column204:
said: “I’m happy to join a company that is changing the way insurance is sold and is serious about creating new ways to utilise technology and data to protect its customers from fraud. My aim at INSHUR is to deploy the most cutting edge systems to detect and prevent fraud and see that these processes mirror the seamless experience in purchasing a policy from us.”

\n\n

Prior to joining INSHUR Peter Truong was a Senior Business Intelligence Consultant working on business intelligence solutions across a range of industries including Banking
column205: Insurance
column207:
Marketing and Public Services.

\n\n

Talking about his new role
column208: Peter Truong
column209: Senior Business Intelligence Developer
column210: said: “Working with the team at INSHUR
column211: I intend to consolidate the huge amounts of data the organisation has access to
column212:
so we can develop frameworks and processes that will enable consistent and accurate business intelligence to both our partners and clients.”

\n\n

Milan Chavda has extensive pricing and actuarial experience
column213: working within the insurance industry across multiple underwriting and broker functions having worked at the BGL group
column215:
ERS and Complete Cover Group.

\n\n

Milan Chavda
column216: Head of Pricing
column217: said: “My focus is on strategic pricing
column219:
optimising prices and reviewing the actuarial performance of the insurance business. I look forward to getting to grips with INSHUR’s platform so I can apply advanced analytical techniques to the UK and US portfolios to ensure maximum success for the business.”

\n\n

With over 13 years’ experience in the insurance industry
column220: having formerly worked as Head of Innovation at Beazley
column221:
John King brings a wealth of experience from the client side. At Beazley John spent most of his time searching and interviewing insurtech companies to look for ways to innovate the traditional insurance model.

\n\n

John King
column222: Head of Product
column223: said: “In my previous roles I have seen a massive disconnect between what the insurance companies were trying to do and what their customers actually needed. INSHUR is different
column224: focusing on their users first and foremost
column225: and then looking at how to make sure they deliver that product in a useful and meaningful way. It’s a more human way of doing insurance
column226:
which immediately attracted me to the company.”

column1: 154	Canberk	Mike Barrett	Person	https://www.risk.net/risk-management/7653726/driving-anti-money-laundering-efficiency-gains-using-artificial-intelligence	"Anti-money laundering (AML) is expensive and labour-intensive
column2: and artificial intelligence (AI) can offer improved efficiency gains. Could they be a match made in heaven? This Risk.net webinar
column3: in association with NICE Actimize
column4: took place amid the strain on banks’ back offices driven by the lockdown in response to the global Covid‑19 pandemic
column5: and explores this potential pairing

column1: Today’s evolving regulatory environment and criminal typologies have influenced AML compliance teams to adopt AI technologies such as machine learning to improve detection and better focus analyst workloads.

The marriage of AI to existing compliance processes and risk modelling techniques has the potential to eliminate backlogs and create new efficiencies. But there may be some risks and question marks for those in the early stages of adoption.

The strain on many financial institutions has only increased in 2020 due to the unexpected arrival of Covid‑19. The subsequent lockdown presented enormous challenges. Fraud and AML teams are now – almost without exception – working from home
column2: and the typical behaviour of corporate and retail customers has been inverted.

column1: Problems around budgets
column2: resources and priorities remain or have been redoubled for financial institutions. Regulators are still issuing fines for AML foul-ups. Financial criminals
column3: meanwhile
column4: are engaging in new rounds of scams and schemes to take advantage of the Covid‑19 pandemic.

column1: “Clients are trading differently today than they were previously
column2: and there’s a lot of volatility in the market
column3: ” said a chief compliance officer for a large European bank. “Most systems are calibrated to detect unusual activity
column4: whether that’s increased volumes or changes in clients’ trading patterns. Consequently
column5: there’s a lot more strain on our detection systems and our transaction monitoring guys are being kept very busy.”

column1: The compliance head saw a rise in false positives
column2: in part due to limitations on calibrating existing systems and the inability to anticipate current crisis event behaviours
column3: warning that criminals and scammers are also ramping up activity.

column1: “When you have a situation like Covid-19
column2: the criminal fraternity see that as a great opportunity to try and test control frameworks within banks. We’ve seen an increase in the level of people who we would reject normally
column3: and in any other situation they would not even attempt to open an account
column4: ” he said.

column1: “The old classic scams
column2: such as ‘I have $350 million tied up in a bank account in Nigeria; I just need this signature and some details’
column3: had dissipated somewhat. Now
column4: the scammers are back in force
column5: using the pandemic situation to phish for an opportunity

column1: Every crisis represents an opportunity for financial crime specialists looking to exploit the public
column2: emphasised Andrew Fleming
column3: global compliance MI
column4: senior risk reporting manager at HSBC. This has led to a rise in scammers offering funds and posing as government or medical authorities to commit fraud.

column1: “We’ve seen a number of these sorts of things already coming into play. One of my favourites was somebody in the US offering toothpaste that cured the disease
column2: ” said Fleming.

column1: Covid‑19 could be a catalyst for creating more automation within banking processes
column2: Fleming suggested
column3: particularly if the illness or inability to work causes gaps in the ranks of teams working in risk and compliance roles.

column1: “This pandemic could drive changes at a faster pace. It demonstrates the vulnerability of the human workforce and concentrates business minds on how they can derive value from the automation of processes
column2: through robotic process automation and machine learning
column3: and even deep learning
column4: which is beginning to come into the fray
column5: ” he said.

column1: “We’ve been looking at automation and driving digital change within the banking structure
column2: ” continued Fleming. “Machines might get the occasional virus that needs fixing but they’re not working from home and they work in a structure. Machines run 24 hours a day
column3: seven days a week – and they’re driving efficiencies throughout the process.”

column1: From a service provider’s perspective
column2: Michael Barrett
column3: senior director
column4: product management
column5: AML
column7: agreed that the pandemic has created an impetus for banks now that their focus is on operational efficiency and resilience.

column1: “The need for technology to address some investigation elements is greater now than it ever has been before
column2: ” said Barrett. “Covid-19 has been a wake‑up call for many banking customers
column3: some of whom had initiatives on the back burner to automate or streamline processes and address inefficiencies. Now they are in a situation where it’s front and centre of their agendas because they’re under pressure
column4: and reliance on human interaction has become problematic.”

column1: Seeing the wood for the trees

Big corporate customers for banks – such as retail department stores – are seeing an unprecedented drop in footfall in their premises since Covid‑19 lockdowns took effect. Some firms have gone into administration
column2: while online shopping businesses are booming.

column1: “Within that online demand you also get greater opportunity for financial crime
column2: ” Fleming said. “Fraudsters and money launderers are taking advantage of the situation because the volume of transactions is increasing
column3: and companies may have a shortfall of staff because of sickness or be adapting to working remotely. Consequently
column4: they are gambling that companies may miss fraudulent transactions that
column5: under normal circumstances

column1: Meanwhile
column2: for money launderers
column3: the Covid‑19 lockdown presents a different type of challenge because their schemes rely on cash-based businesses
column4: such as barbers
column5: tanning salons and car washes. “These criminals haven’t gone away. We still have drug dealers and fraudsters
column6: and they need to get money into the system

column1: “These people will look to use enablers
column2: such as gatekeeper professionals
column3: to get around systems. They may create new companies to try and demonstrate that they’ve got legitimate sources for funds. We’re going to be challenged with identifying these companies and identifying where this criminal money is now coming in
column4: ” he warned.

column1: The chief compliance officer cautioned that the sudden changes in behaviour across society are making it harder – it’s increasingly difficult to spot the good money from the bad.
“Covid‑19 has triggered a massive change in behaviour across the board. We’re not a retail bank
column2: so we’re more involved in combating the layering stage of money laundering
column3: but we are seeing very strange behaviours from a number of our clients
column4: ” he said.

column1: “That could be because they’ve started to launder money or it could just be a function of what’s going on in the market. We’re using up a lot more time and energy investigating those alerts than previously. It’s quite a challenge to see the wood for the trees
column2: ” he added.

column1: Barrett proposed actions to address that challenge. First
column2: by establishing what has gone wrong with the existing systems unable to cope with inverted transaction behaviour
column3: and how these systems need to be refined.

column1: “The first element to address is to perform some rapid tuning
column2: ” Barrett said. “We have an ActimizeWatch service
column3: which allows us to monitor and understand where systems are degrading.”

column1: “Where there’s a spike in alerts and unexpected behaviour
column2: we’re able to model that with our own data science team on behalf of our customers
column3: which can then provide the client with recommendations for thresholds to adjust. That’s a great way of us being able to quickly identify where a system needs to be refined
column4: ” he explained.

column1: Opportunists among the criminals represent another challenge
column2: Barrett suggested
column3: requiring a focus on looking at new typologies and new behaviours. Suspicious behaviour patterns are emerging fast
column4: and need to be found and captured quickly.

column1: “In instances where cash-based industries have had no revenue for weeks or months
column2: similar companies still operating a high turnover could be suspicious. Therefore
column3: we’re working to analyse the potential for analytics based on behaviour by industry code as an example
column4: ” he said.

column1: Of course
column2: one danger with tweaking systems to detect unusual behaviours during crises is that
column3: once normal conditions resume
column4: a system could continue to identify trends that no longer apply.

column1: “Absolutely
column2: that’s a danger. We can’t model the new normal as the normal forever
column3: ” Barrett responded. “It will change again
column4: and things will readapt and hopefully settle back down into a more consistent pattern. However
column5: if current behaviour lasts for weeks or months
column6: that’s too long to ignore. So we need to learn quickly now
column7: then we need to adapt again once we are trending back into what would be the traditional normal pattern.”

column1: Fleming agreed that model analysis element and dynamic risk assessment is exactly what’s needed. “We need to be able to develop new tools and strategies that are able to adapt in a dynamic risk situation. That includes being able to rapidly tune these technologies to meet the changing landscape
column2: ” he said.

column1: Typical legacy systems at many banks lack the flexibility to be used dynamically
column2: Fleming noted
column3: taking too long to fix and change. “These new technologies need to be much quicker at adapting to new threats and new scenarios that come to the fore
column4: ” said Barrett. “I think every business has to be more agile in how it deals with threats. If we don’t do that then we’re going to get caught out.”

column1: Approaches to machine learning
AML is just one of many applications for machine learning technology. Barrett gave his perspective on its use
column2: beginning with the critical task of clustering and segmenting data
column3: from which anomalies can be found
column4: accurately targeting suspicious elements for any given data.

column1: He described ‘step one’ for targeted detection towards getting better results from models: “We have machine learning models that assist with that clustering process
column2: which carves out the data in the most effective way in the first place. Then we have additional AI technology that takes those segments and applies machine learning techniques to develop tuning thresholds and policies associated with those segments.”

column1: He added: “Those technologies come hand in hand. Segmentation and optimised tuning are a package of machine learning we develop that allows for that automatic tuning based on precisely targeted segments
column2: ” he added.

column1: The second step uses predictive models to learn the human investigation process
column2: overlaying the human intelligence of the compliance team onto the systems themselves.

column1: “Let’s learn about those investigations and factor that in as part of a model to feed back on any new alerts that have been produced. That way we can understand and provide insights into the likelihood of those alerts being particularly suspicious or
column2: alternatively
column3: even candidates for hibernation
column4: ” Barrett said.

column1: “The third aspect is to provide machine learning models to introduce new detection capabilities themselves
column2: by producing models for advanced anomaly detection
column3: to allow for new typologies to be introduced
column4: and so on
column5: ” he added.

column1: Fleming added to this the need to demonstrate that internal controls are effective and the right governing structures are in place for delivering what’s needed for the customer
column2: the business and the regulator. This means placing a focus on those controls and the supporting governance to ensure they are delivering what is required
column3: he underlined.

column1: “First of all
column2: you want to be able to provide the customers with a seamless service that makes the end-to-end processing as painless as possible
column3: ” he said. “Second
column4: you want to be able to protect the business and identify and reduce risks earlier on
column5: driving operational efficiencies and effectiveness. We also want to be able to demonstrate to the regulators what we’re doing and how we’re managing risks effectively.”

column1: New toys
Regulators have been somewhat neutral about AI and machine learning
column2: in some instances encouraging innovation
column3: but without specifying much in the way of good or bad practice – or what compliance benefits or pitfalls may await firms that innovate.

column1: “Certainly
column2: the UK regulator has never sanctioned any type of AI or machine learning products or processes
column3: ” said the chief compliance officer. “The regulator’s view is realistic; it’s that financial institutions should have systems and controls commensurate with the size and complexity of their business.

column1: “If you tell them you’re processing a million payments a day
column2: there is no way you can effectively screen them all without a sophisticated system that is well tested
column3: checked and maintained. One of the few things regulators don’t mandate is whether any of your AML processes are automated. You could hire 10
column4: 000 people to do all your checks manually. You might go bust doing it
column5: but you wouldn’t be in breach of the rules.”

column1: On the other hand
column2: the chief compliance officer noted regulatory dissatisfaction when
column3: the regulators having conducted their investigations
column4: they found out firms had invested in sophisticated technology but were then lax or incompetent in the testing
column5: maintenance or use of it.

column1: “Firms can shoot themselves in the foot
column2: ” he continued. “There are final notices mentioning when the regulator went into a certain firm they were disappointed to find that
column3: although it had spent millions of pounds on various systems
column4: the firm either hadn’t switched them on properly
column5: or were just using the factory settings.”

column1: Firms will get little sympathy from the regulator if they are investing in technology they don’t understand or don’t use properly
column2: Fleming agreed. “The regulator is concerned that you understand you own the risk. Just because you’ve brought in a new toy – and no matter what the new technology is – they want to see it’s producing better results
column3: and that you’re taking responsibility for it.”

column1: Rare is the firm that chooses to build all its systems itself. Service providers therefore play an important role in providing regulatory confidence in their clients’ AML systems and models
column2: and the governance in place to manage them responsibly.

column1: “To meet governance expectations
column2: evidence is provided on a number of different levels of detail right down to the specific algorithms used and the data attributes being fed in – everything around how the models are tuned to a specific customer environment
column3: ” said Barrett.

column1: Transparency is a big part of this
column2: he explained
column3: requiring detailed dashboards to track model performance
column4: allowing customers to peek under the bonnet and intervene when necessary.

column1: Below-the-line testing strategies represent another key element to building regulators’ confidence for a new machine learning model
column2: Barrett added. “Below-the-line testing is a key weapon in the armoury for ensuring that AML systems are strong
column3: secure and doing exactly what they’re supposed to be doing
column4: ” he said.

column1: “It’s vital there’s a solid below-the-line testing strategy in place. That’s so we can prove if all the thresholds are moved
column2: or different rules are put in place
column3: that these would be the events that would be produced
column4: and if you investigated them you would understand that there is no suspicious behaviour there.”

column1: Specialist skills

Part of that competence involves the skills of the AML teams tasked increasingly with managing technology as well as people. The skills required are inevitably shifting with the tools and techniques used.
Fleming said: “We have a good number of data scientists
column2: but whether or not we have the right specialties in place to be good at working on the various types of financial crime
column3: AML
column4: fraud
column5: tax evasion and tackling terrorism financing
column6: I suspect not. You want to get the right people
column8: and you do need to pay for that.”

column1: The chief compliance officer agreed
column2: adding that he had embarked on a part-time data science course. “Maybe I’m one of the compliance people that’s seen the light and is heading towards the data science field.” He suggested that
column3: while there are probably enough data scientists on the payroll
column4: AML specialist background experience is harder to come by and expensive.

column1: “The population Venn diagram of those data scientists that cross over with any AML knowledge is very small
column2: and that can put them beyond the budget that firms are willing to spend
column3: ” he said.

column1: “Before you can get people to start committing budget to these things
column2: you really have to make sure the organisation has made a commitment to being data-driven from the top. By that I mean having a chief executive officer and heads of compliance and risk who are tech-savvy themselves and understand the benefits.”

column1: As a service provider
column2: Barrett tries to supplement clients’ expertise with that of his own team
column3: allowing them to focus their own resources on the crucial modelling efforts.

column1: “We’ll build the infrastructure
column2: we’ll flatten the data
column3: we’ll provide the tooling. Our customers’ data science teams can then use that tooling to actually do the modelling
column4: ” he said. “We feel we can really help our customers have a laser-focused approach to doing modelling work and applying their data science minds in the right way.”"	"[{'query': {'id': '1605093875548-71f146f5022d4d01'
