column335: and artificial intelligence (AI)\xa0can offer improved efficiency gains. Could they be a match made in heaven? This Risk.net webinar
column337: took place amid the strain on banks’ back offices driven by the lockdown in response to the global Covid‑19 pandemic
column338:
and explores this potential pairing

\n\n
column339:
NICE Actimize"" src=""https://www.risk.net/sites/risk/files/styles/portrait_230_372/public/2020-07/Mike%20Barrett%2C%20NICE%20Actimize.jpg?itok=zzkp1VsR"">

Today’s evolving regulatory environment and criminal typologies have influenced AML\xa0compliance teams to adopt AI technologies such as machine learning to improve detection and better focus analyst workloads.

The marriage of AI to existing compliance processes and risk modelling techniques has the potential to eliminate backlogs and create new efficiencies. But there may be some risks and question marks for those in the early stages of adoption.

The strain on many financial institutions has only increased in 2020 due to the unexpected arrival of Covid‑19. The subsequent lockdown presented enormous challenges. Fraud and AML teams are now\xa0– almost without exception\xa0– working from home
column340:
and the typical behaviour of corporate and retail customers has been inverted.

\n\n

Problems around budgets
column341: resources and priorities remain or have been redoubled for financial institutions. Regulators are still issuing fines for AML foul-ups. Financial criminals
column343:
are engaging in new rounds of scams and schemes to take advantage of the Covid‑19 pandemic.

\n\n

“Clients are trading differently today than they were previously
column344: and there’s a lot of volatility in the market
column345: ” said a chief compliance officer for a large European bank. “Most systems are calibrated to detect unusual activity
column346: whether that’s increased volumes or changes in clients’ trading patterns. Consequently
column347:
there’s a lot more strain on our detection systems and our transaction monitoring guys are being kept very busy.”

\n\n

The compliance head saw a rise in false positives
column348: in part due to limitations on calibrating existing systems and the inability to anticipate current crisis event behaviours
column349:
warning that criminals and scammers are also ramping up activity.

\n\n

“When you have a situation like Covid-19
column350: the criminal fraternity see that as a great opportunity to try and test control frameworks within banks. We’ve seen an increase in the level of people who we would reject normally
column351: and in any other situation they would not even attempt to open an account
column353: such as ‘I have $350\xa0million tied up in a bank account in Nigeria; I just need this signature and some details’
column355: the scammers are back in force
column356: using the pandemic situation to phish for an opportunity
column357:
” the chief compliance officer added.

\n\n

Every crisis represents an opportunity for financial crime specialists looking to exploit the public
column360:
senior risk reporting manager at HSBC. This has led to a rise in scammers offering funds and posing as government or medical authorities to commit fraud.

\n\n

“We’ve seen a number of these sorts of things already coming into play. One of my favourites was somebody in the US offering toothpaste that cured the disease
column361:
” said Fleming.

\n\n

Covid‑19 could be a catalyst for creating more automation within banking processes
column363:
particularly if the illness or inability to work causes gaps in the ranks of teams working in risk and compliance roles.

\n\n

“This pandemic could drive changes at a faster pace. It demonstrates the vulnerability of the human workforce and concentrates business minds on how they can derive value from the automation of processes
column364: through robotic process automation and machine learning
column366: which is beginning to come into the fray
column367:
” he said.

\n\n

“We’ve been looking at automation and driving digital change within the banking structure
column368: ” continued Fleming. “Machines might get the occasional virus that needs fixing but they’re not working from home and they work in a structure. Machines run 24 hours a day
column369:
seven days a week\xa0– and they’re driving efficiencies throughout the process.”

\n\n

From a service provider’s perspective
column375:
agreed that the pandemic has created an impetus for banks now that their focus is on operational efficiency and\xa0resilience.

\n\n

“The need for technology to address some investigation elements is greater now than it ever has been before
column376: ” said Barrett. “Covid-19 has been a wake‑up call for many banking customers
column377: some of whom had initiatives on the back burner to automate or streamline processes and address inefficiencies. Now they are in a situation where it’s front and centre of their agendas because they’re under pressure
column378:
and reliance on human interaction has become\xa0problematic.”

Seeing the wood for the trees

Big corporate customers for banks\xa0– such as retail department stores\xa0– are seeing an unprecedented drop in footfall in their premises since Covid‑19 lockdowns took effect. Some firms have gone into administration
column379:
while online shopping businesses are\xa0booming.

\n\n

“Within that online demand you also get greater opportunity for financial crime
column380: ” Fleming said. “Fraudsters and money launderers are taking advantage of the situation because the volume of transactions is increasing
column381: and companies may have a shortfall of staff because of sickness or be adapting to working remotely. Consequently
column382: they are gambling that companies may miss fraudulent transactions that
column386: the Covid‑19 lockdown presents a different type of challenge because their schemes rely on cash-based businesses
column388: tanning salons and car washes. “These criminals haven’t gone away. We still have drug dealers and fraudsters
column389: and they need to get money into the system
column390:
” Fleming said.

\n\n

“These people will look to use enablers
column392: to get around systems. They may create new companies to try and demonstrate that they’ve got legitimate sources for funds. We’re going to be challenged with identifying these companies and identifying where this criminal money is now coming in
column393:
” he warned.

The chief compliance officer cautioned that the sudden changes in behaviour across society are making it harder – it’s increasingly difficult to spot the good money from the bad.

“Covid‑19 has triggered a massive change in behaviour across the board. We’re not a retail bank
column394: so we’re more involved in combating the layering stage of money laundering
column395: but we are seeing very strange behaviours from a number of our clients
column396:
” he said.

\n\n

“That could be because they’ve started to launder money or it could just be a function of what’s going on in the market. We’re using up a lot more time and energy investigating those alerts than previously. It’s quite a challenge to see the wood for the trees
column397:
” he added.

\n\n

Barrett proposed actions to address that challenge. First
column398: by establishing what has gone wrong with the existing systems unable to cope with inverted transaction behaviour
column399:
and how these systems need to be refined.

\n\n

“The first element to address is to perform some rapid tuning
column400: ” Barrett said. “We have an ActimizeWatch service
column401:
which allows us to monitor and understand where systems are degrading.”

\n\n

“Where there’s a spike in alerts and unexpected behaviour
column402: we’re able to model that with our own data science team on behalf of our customers
column403: which can then provide the client with recommendations for thresholds to adjust. That’s a great way of us being able to quickly identify where a system needs to be refined
column404:
” he explained.

\n\n

Opportunists among the criminals represent another challenge
column406: requiring a focus on looking at new typologies and new behaviours. Suspicious behaviour patterns are emerging fast
column407:
and need to be found and captured quickly.

\n\n

“In instances where cash-based industries have had no revenue for weeks or months
column408: similar companies still operating a high turnover could be suspicious. Therefore
column409: we’re working to analyse the potential for analytics based on behaviour by industry code as an example
column411: one danger with tweaking systems to detect unusual behaviours during crises is that
column413:
a system could continue to identify trends that no longer\xa0apply.

\n\n

“Absolutely
column414: that’s a danger. We can’t model the new normal as the normal forever
column416: and things will readapt and hopefully settle back down into a more consistent pattern. However
column417: if current behaviour lasts for weeks or months
column418: that’s too long to ignore. So we need to learn quickly now
column419:
then we need to adapt again once we are trending back into what would be the traditional normal pattern.”

\n\n

Fleming agreed that model analysis element and dynamic risk assessment is exactly what’s needed. “We need to be able to develop new tools and strategies that are able to adapt in a dynamic risk situation. That includes being able to rapidly tune these technologies to meet the changing landscape
column420:
” he said.

\n\n

Typical legacy systems at many banks lack the flexibility to be used dynamically
column422: taking too long to fix and change. “These new technologies need to be much quicker at adapting to new threats and new scenarios that come to the fore
column423:
” said Barrett. “I think every business has to be more agile in how it deals with threats. If we don’t do that then we’re going to get caught out.”

Approaches to machine learning\xa0

AML is just one of many applications for machine learning technology. Barrett gave his perspective on its use
column424: beginning with the critical task of clustering and segmenting data
column425: from which anomalies can be found
column426:
accurately targeting suspicious elements for any given data.

\n\n

He described ‘step one’ for targeted detection towards getting better results from models: “We have machine learning models that assist with that clustering process
column427:
which carves out the data in the most effective way in the first place. Then we have additional AI technology that takes those segments and applies machine learning techniques to develop tuning thresholds and policies associated with those segments.”

\n\n

He added: “Those technologies come hand in hand. Segmentation and optimised tuning are a package of machine learning we develop that allows for that automatic tuning based on precisely targeted segments
column428:
” he added.

\n\n

The second step uses predictive models to learn the human investigation process
column429:
overlaying the human intelligence of the compliance team onto the systems themselves.

\n\n

“Let’s learn about those investigations and factor that in as part of a model to feed back on any new alerts that have been produced. That way we can understand and provide insights into the likelihood of those alerts being particularly suspicious or
column432:
” Barrett\xa0said.

\n\n

“The third aspect is to provide machine learning models to introduce new detection capabilities themselves
column433: by producing models for advanced anomaly detection
column434: to allow for new typologies to be introduced
column436:
” he added.

\n\n

Fleming added to this the need to demonstrate that internal controls are effective and the right governing structures are in place for delivering what’s needed for the customer
column437: the business and the regulator. This means placing a focus on those controls and the supporting governance to ensure they are delivering what is required
column439: you want to be able to provide the customers with a seamless service that makes the end-to-end processing as painless as possible
column441: you want to be able to protect the business and identify and reduce risks earlier on
column442:
driving operational efficiencies and effectiveness. We also want to be able to demonstrate to the regulators what we’re doing and how we’re managing risks effectively.”

New toys

Regulators have been somewhat neutral about AI and machine learning
column444:
but without specifying much in the way of good or bad practice – or what compliance benefits or pitfalls may await firms that innovate.

\n\n

“Certainly
column445: the UK regulator has never sanctioned any type of AI or machine learning products or processes
column446:
” said the chief compliance officer. “The regulator’s view is realistic; it’s that financial institutions should have systems and controls commensurate with the size and complexity of their business.

\n\n

“If you tell them you’re processing a million payments a day
column447: there is no way you can effectively screen them all without a sophisticated system that is well tested
column448: checked and maintained. One of the few things regulators don’t mandate is whether any of your AML processes are automated. You could hire 10
column449: 000 people to do all your checks manually. You might go bust doing it
column450:
but you wouldn’t be in breach of the rules.”

\n\n

On the other hand
column451: the chief compliance officer noted regulatory dissatisfaction when
column452: the regulators having conducted their investigations
column453: they found out firms had invested in sophisticated technology but were then lax or incompetent in the testing
column454:
maintenance or use of it.

\n\n

“Firms can shoot themselves in the foot
column455: ” he continued. “There are final notices mentioning when the regulator went into a certain firm they were disappointed to find that
column456: although it had spent millions of pounds on various systems
column457: the firm either hadn’t switched them on properly
column458:
or were just using the factory settings.”

\n\n

Firms will get little sympathy from the regulator if they are investing in technology they don’t understand or don’t use properly
column459: Fleming agreed. “The regulator is concerned that you understand you own the risk. Just because you’ve brought in a new toy – and no matter what the new technology is – they want to see it’s producing better results
column460:
and that you’re taking responsibility for it.”

\n\n

Rare is the firm that chooses to build all its systems itself. Service providers therefore play an important role in providing regulatory confidence in their clients’ AML systems and models
column461:
and the governance in place to manage them responsibly.

\n\n

“To meet governance expectations
column462: evidence is provided on a number of different levels of detail right down to the specific algorithms used and the data attributes being fed in\xa0– everything around how the models are tuned to a specific customer environment
column463:
” said Barrett.

\n\n

Transparency is a big part of this
column465: requiring detailed dashboards to track model performance
column466:
allowing customers to peek under the bonnet and intervene when necessary.

\n\n

Below-the-line testing strategies represent another key element to building regulators’ confidence for a new machine learning model
column467: Barrett added. “Below-the-line testing is a key weapon in the armoury for ensuring that AML systems are strong
column468: secure and doing exactly what they’re supposed to be doing
column469:
” he said.

\n\n

“It’s vital there’s a solid below-the-line testing strategy in place. That’s so we can prove if all the thresholds are moved
column470: or different rules are put in place
column471: that these would be the events that would be produced
column472:
and if you investigated them you would understand that there is no suspicious behaviour there.”

Specialist skills

Part of that competence involves the skills of the AML teams tasked increasingly with managing technology as well as people. The skills required are inevitably shifting with the tools and techniques used.

Fleming said: “We have a good number of data scientists
column473: but whether or not we have the right specialties in place to be good at working on the various types of financial crime
column476: tax evasion and tackling terrorism financing
column477: I suspect not. You want to get the right people
column479:
and you do need to pay for that.”

\n\n

The chief compliance officer agreed
column480: adding that he had embarked on a part-time data science course. “Maybe I’m one of the compliance people that’s seen the light and is heading towards the data science field.” He suggested that
column481: while there are probably enough data scientists on the payroll
column482:
AML specialist background experience is harder to come by and expensive.

\n\n

“The population Venn diagram of those data scientists that cross over with any AML knowledge is very small
column483: and that can put them beyond the budget that firms are willing to spend
column484:
” he said.

\n\n

“Before you can get people to start committing budget to these things
column485:
you really have to make sure the organisation has made a commitment to being data-driven from the top. By that I mean having a chief executive officer and heads of compliance and risk who are tech-savvy themselves and understand the\xa0benefits.”

\n\n

As a service provider
column486: Barrett tries to supplement clients’ expertise with that of his own team
column487:
allowing them to focus their own resources on the crucial modelling efforts.

\n\n

“We’ll build the infrastructure
column489: we’ll provide the tooling. Our customers’ data science teams can then use that tooling to actually do the modelling
column490:
” he said. “We feel we can really help our customers have a laser-focused approach to doing modelling work and applying their data science minds in the right way.”

column1: 330	Sebastien	Grace Mugabe	individual	https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/dec/19/south-african-police-issue-arrest-warrant-for-grace-mugabe-zimbabwe-accused-assault-hotel	"South Africa has issued an arrest warrant for Zimbabwe’s former first lady Grace Mugabe in relation to an alleged assault on a woman in a hotel in Johannesburg last year.

Gabriella Engels accused Mugabe of beating the “hell out” of her with an electrical extension cord in a room at the Capital 20 West hotel in Johannesburg’s Sandton district. After the alleged assault came to light in August 2017
column2: the South African government granted Mugabe diplomatic immunity. That immunity was overturned by a court this year after Engels
column3: a model
column4: challenged the decision.

column1: “I can confirm that a warrant for the arrest of Grace Mugabe was issued last Thursday
column2: ” said Vishnu Naidoo
column3: a spokesman for South Africa’s police service. He said police were seeking Interpol’s help to enforce the warrant.

column1: There was no immediate comment from Grace Mugabe.
The two countries have an extradition agreement
column2: but Zimbabwe’s deputy minister for information
column3: Energy Mutodi
column4: told Reuters that Harare would not extradite Mugabe.

column1: “I believe the government of Zimbabwe will not tolerate any harassment or degrading treatment on the former president Mugabe and his immediate family members
column2: ” Mutodi said
column3: adding that he would need to consult with President Emmerson Mnangagwa on a final decision.

column1: Grace Mugabe
column3: was seen as a potential successor to her 94-year-old husband
column4: Robert Mugabe
column5: who ruled Zimbabwe from 1980 until he was ousted in a coup late last year.

column1: She has denied assaulting Engels with an extension cord
column2: saying an “intoxicated and unhinged” Engels attacked her with a knife after going to see the Mugabe’s sons at the hotel. The South African advocacy group AfriForum
column3: which represented Engels
column4: has accused Mugabe of lying.

column1: Mugabe has retreated from the limelight in Zimbabwe since her husband was ousted. Elections in August were won by Mnangagwa
column2: his former righthand man in the ruling Zanu-PF party.

column1: The warrant comes days after a long-awaited report into the killing of six people by soldiers during a post-elections protest in Harare. On Thursday
column2: opposition figures dismissed the inquiry’s findings as “an effort to whitewash the killing of innocent lives”.

column1: Set up by Mnangagwa
column2: the inquiry found that the military and police were responsible for the deaths
column3: but that the deployment of troops had been lawful after the police had been overwhelmed by protesters. The protests were “pre-planned and orchestrated” and leaders from the main opposition party
column4: the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC)
column5: had incited violence

column1: It recommended that soldiers should face “internal” disciplinary measures if found to have broken their codes of conduct.
Jacob Mafume
column2: a spokesperson for the MDC
column3: described the inquiry’s conclusions as “bizarre”
column4: telling the Guardian: “They say it’s the MDC that incited violence yet blame the military for shooting the people.”

column1: Opposition leaders have denied the charge of incitement.
The violence followed relatively peaceful elections and caused significant political difficulties for Mnangagwa’s government
column2: which has made strenuous attempts to convince the international community that Zanu-PF has forgone the repression and brutality it was accused of during its 38 years in power under Mugabe.

column71: society figure and now a recipient of a presidential pardon was in the public spotlight for years. Deported to Canada in 2012 after spending more than three years in prison
column72:
Black had been found guilty of fraud and obstruction of justice. His long and colorful history includes a long-standing alliance with President Trump.

\n\n

Born in Canada
column73: Black eventually became a British lord and is described in\xa0press accounts as a millionaire who lived like a billionaire. When criticized for allegedly using shareholder money to finance a vacation to Bora Bora and charging an extravagant birthday party for his wife to his company
column74:
he reportedly declared that he would ""not re-enact the French Revolutionary renunciation of the rights of the nobility."" He was acquitted of charges related to both incidents.

""A President Like No Other""

In his 20s
column75: Black and longtime business partner David Radler turned an investment in an English-language daily in Quebec into a company that ran more than 300 newspapers. He became a convicted felon decades later when he and other executives were accused of looting about $32 million from Hollinger International
column76: which owned entities including the Chicago Sun-Times
column77: Canada\'s National Post
column78:
the U.K.\'s Daily Telegraph and the Jerusalem Post. Radler pleaded guilty in the scheme blamed for taking down what at the time was among the biggest newspaper companies in the world.

\n\n

When Black was at the helm
column79: the Sun-Times in the early 2000s sold its building alongside the Chicago River to Mr. Trump
column80:
leading to the present-day Trump International Hotel & Tower Chicago. The two were partners in the undertaking until Mr. Trump bought out Black.

\n\n

The full pardon came a day after the National Review published an essay by Black headlined: ""Smooth Sailing Ahead for Trump
column81: and a year after the publication of Black\'s book
column82: ""Donald J. Trump: A President Like No Other."" The 74-year-old Black has authored other presidential biographies
column83: including ""Richard M. Nixon: A Life in Full
column84:
in 2007.

\n\n

""Mr. Black is entirely deserving"" of the pardon
column85: the White House said in a\xa0statement. It touted him as having made ""tremendous contributions to business
column86:
as well as to political and historical thought.""

\n\n

column1: 80	Sebastien	Jean Chrétien	individual	https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2005/02/cana-f19.html	"Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin and Jean Chrétien
column2: his predecessor as head of the Liberal government
column3: testified under oath last week at a public inquiry investigating alleged government corruption. Only once previously did a sitting or past Canadian prime minister give public testimony in a like judicial proceeding. That was in 1873
column4: when Canada’s first prime minister
column5: Sir John A. Macdonald
column6: responded to charges his government had awarded a railway contract in return for massive election campaign contributions to his Conservative Party.

column1: At Martin’s request
column2: Justice John Gomery is investigating a federal government program under which Ottawa paid out $250 million between 1996 and 2002 to sponsor sporting and cultural events. Much of the money was funnelled through Liberal-friendly advertising firms. It is not uncommon for Canadian governments
column3: whether federal or provincial
column4: to steer government advertising and consultancy work to firms known to be friendly to the party in power. But in this case
column5: internal government audits found the program improperly managed
column6: with financial records either nonexistent or replete with errors and gaps.

column1: A government study of contracts given to Le Groupe Polygone Editeurs
column2: which received $40 million in sponsorship money
column3: said that there appeared to have been “systematic and egregious overcharging for what was delivered.” A subsequent investigation by Canada’s auditor-general found repeated instances of Groupe Polygone and other firms receiving large payments in return for little or no work. Criminal charges have been laid against several advertising company executives.

column1: There is little doubt some people criminally profited from the sponsorship program. There are also good grounds to believe that the program—whose ostensible purpose was to raise the profile of the federal government in Quebec and thereby counter the Quebec indépendantiste movement—was used to finance the Quebec wing of the Liberal Party. According to Alfonso Gagliano
column2: who for much of this period was both the minister responsible for the sponsorship program and the boss of the Quebec Liberal machine
column3: the Liberal Party was “not rich.” It
column4: however
column5: did receive substantial donations from many of the firms and executives of the firms that received sponsorship contracts from Gagliano’s Public Works Ministry or to which sponsorship work was subcontracted.

column1: That said
column2: the sponsorship scandal—the blaring headlines and feigned outrage of opposition politicians notwithstanding—is pretty much small potatoes. As the doyen of Canadian political journalism Peter C. Newman conceded
column3: patronage has always been integral to the functioning of Canada’s major political parties. “Patronage
column4: ” wrote Newman in a recent op-ed piece
column5: “is the udder of Canadian democracy. It has fuelled Canadian politics since Sir John A. Macdonald
column7: accepted bribes from would-be builders of the CPR.”

column1: The enormous amount of air-time and ink the corporate media have devoted to the sponsorship scandal and the place it has taken in the official political debate stand in sharp contrast to the treatment accorded other cases of political corruption. Take
column2: for example
column3: the millions of dollars in questionable contracts that high-level operatives in the Ontario Tory government and Ontario Conservative Party were given by the province’s Crown-owned hydro companies between 1995 and 2003. As in the sponsorship scandal
column4: many of the contracts called for little if any real work. Yet the press soon dropped the story.

column1: And what of the revelation that Karlheinz Schreiber
column2: a German-Canadian arms dealer whom the German government is seeking to extradite
column3: paid former Progressive Conservative Prime Minister Brian Mulroney $300
column4: 000—in cash
column5: in hotel rooms—shortly after he left office? Although Mulroney’s explanation—that the money was in return for the advice he gave Schreiber on a pasta-manufacturing scheme—is
column8: few newspapers reported on Schreiber’s payments to Mulroney. None has pursued the story.

column1: If the sponsorship scandal has become such a major political issue
column2: it is because it has served as a mechanism through which Canada’s corporate and political elite have fought out matters of leadership and policy direction.

column1: The neo-conservative National Post and the official opposition Canadian Alliance—now merged with the Tories in the new Conservative Party—have long-trumpeted allegations of waste and corruption in government spending. They have done so in order to discredit their Liberal rivals and
column2: more generally
column3: with the aim of depicting government spending as out of control
column4: so as to bolster their crusade for tax cuts and for “getting government off the back of Canadians” through privatization and deregulation. In this they have been inspired
column5: if not directly advised
column6: by the US Republicans who used a trumped-up financial scandal
column8: and then the Monica Lewinsky affair to destabilize the Clinton administration and ultimately to try to unseat Clinton.

column1: Paul Martin and his supporters in the Liberal Party and sections of the ruling class who still view the Liberals as the party best able to govern in their interests—because of residual popular illusions in the Liberals’ being a party of the “people” and because of the Liberals’ commitment to a strong federal state—also made use of the sponsorship scandal and other allegations of impropriety in pushing for Chrétien to retire.
And since the release of the auditor-general’s damning report on the sponsorship program last February
column2: Martin and the Conservatives
column3: to say nothing of the pro-independence Bloc Québécois
column4: have all found it in their interest at various times to focus public attention on the sponsorship scandal
column5: so as to avoid discussion of their own records

column1: This choice of means is
column2: of course
column3: not without significance. There is great popular dissatisfaction with
column4: and disaffection from
column5: all the establishment parties
column6: from the avowedly pro-big business Conservatives through the social democrats of the New Democratic Party
column7: because they have all been party to the assault on public and social services and trade union and democratic rights. Because there is no popular constituency for big business’s program of razing what remains of the welfare state
column8: gutting all regulatory restraints on capital
column9: and bringing Canada into a closer economic and geo-political partnership with Wall Street and Washington
column10: big business and its political representatives have increasingly resorted to the politics of scandal and subterfuge and to nationalist and other noxious appeals in moulding and manipulating public opinion.

column1: From Chrétien to Martin
Jean Chrétien
column2: in a lengthy opening statement before Justice Gomery’s inquiry
column3: made an impassioned defence of his government’s record
column4: arguing explicitly that his government had strengthened Canada and implicitly that he had well served the interests of Canadian big business. The Wall Street Journal
column5: he observed
column6: had warned shortly after he came to office that Canada was being reduced to the status of a Third World country. But his government had taken decisive action to put federal finances in order. Boasted Chrétien
column7: “We had 10 great years when we turned it around

column1: Indeed
column2: in terms of socioeconomic and fiscal policy
column3: the Chrétien Liberal government was far and away the most right-wing federal government since the Great Depression. It slashed tens of billions from health care and other public services
column4: rewrote the rules governing Canada’s unemployment insurance program to deny benefits to the majority of the jobless
column5: and
column6: once the annual budget deficit was eliminated
column8: $100 billion program of corporate and personal income tax cuts skewed to benefit the rich and designed to ensure that the state lacked the resources to reinvest in public services.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: big business became increasingly dissatisfied with Chrétien
column3: especially after the coming to power of the Bush administration in 2001. Chrétien’s Trudeau-era Canadian nationalism
column4: with its streak of anti-Americanism
column5: his reluctance to give a massive
column6: multibillion-dollar permanent boost to the military budget
column7: and his failure to publicly promote privatization and deregulation
column8: were all seen as inimical to big business’s interests.

column1: Under conditions where the bourgeoisie’s traditional alternate party of government
column2: the Progressive Conservatives
column3: had been reduced to a rump
column4: the most powerful sections of Canadian business fixed on Martin—himself a multimillionaire businessman and Chrétien’s finance minister—as the best means of unseating Chrétien and shifting the government further right.

column1: Martin was thus egged on in his campaign to seize the leadership of the Liberal Party and prime ministership
column2: the first time a sitting prime minister was felled from within his own party. Although Martin did not directly raise the sponsorship issue during his campaign for the prime ministership
column3: he certainly benefited by press suggestions that financial improprieties had taken place under Chrétien’s watch and alluded to the scandal with his promises of doing politics differently.

column1: What brought the sponsorship scandal to centre-stage was Martin’s decision to fan public outrage over the auditor-general’s report castigating the program. Rather than downplaying the report’s significance
column2: Martin declared himself mad as hell. He hailed the report’s author
column3: Sheila Fraser
column4: as a national hero
column5: asserted that there must have been “political direction” behind the failure to follow normal government procedures in the awarding and administering of contracts
column6: fired Gagliano from his post as Canada’s ambassador to Denmark
column7: and sacked several long-time Liberals from their posts as heads of various Crown Corporations.

column1: Invariably newspaper columnists have presented Martin’s response to the auditor-general’s report as a settling of accounts with Chrétien and his faction of the Liberal Party. Undoubtedly
column2: personal rivalries and power struggles were involved. But Martin’s decision to champion the sponsorship scandal was also rooted in his anxiousness to demonstrate to big business that his government was a new regime
column3: not a continuation of the Chrétien Liberal government.

column1: Martin’s first actions on taking office all signalled a shift to the right. He announced an immediate review of all government spending and a freeze on recently announced expenditures. He stressed his intention to mend fences with the Bush administration and
column2: after an initial get-acquainted meeting with Bush
column3: declared that any differences between the US and Canadian governments over the Iraq war were now history.

column1: The need to seek a popular mandate constrained Martin
column2: however
column3: from fully satisfying business’s demand for a sharp shift to the right
column4: especially in the form of a new round of tax cuts
column5: the gutting of Canada’s Kyoto Accord commitments
column6: and a closer partnership with the US. He and his aides decided instead to amplify the sponsorship scandal
column9: that a new team with different ideas was in power.

column1: The ruse failed. Martin apparently believed the media hype about his being Canada’s most popular political leader and his unique bond with Canadians. But his trumpeting of the sponsorship scandal sent Liberal polling numbers into freefall.
The Conservatives and Bloc Québécois
column2: meanwhile
column3: fastened onto the sponsorship scandal. Both parties made the purported fight against corruption in government the centrepiece of their campaigns for the June 30 federal election. For the Conservatives
column4: the denunciations of Liberal corruption served as means of deflecting popular attention from their right-wing program and party leader Stephen Harper’s record as a neo-conservative ideologue.

column1: The election left the Liberals clinging to power
column2: more than 20 seats short of a majority of in the House of Commons. Moreover
column3: Martin’s room for maneuver was further reduced by the large increase in votes for parties that portray themselves as left-wing opponents of the two major parties
column4: the New Democratic Party
column5: Bloc Québécois and Greens.

column1: Chrétien and Martin before the commission
Chrétien was the first of the two Liberal Party leaders to appear before the Gomery Commission. He ceded nothing to his critics
column2: insisting that the sponsorship program had been an essential part of the federal government’s strategy to fight Quebec separatism
column3: and made his disdain for the commission clear to all.

column1: Earlier Chrétien’s lawyers had pressed for Judge Gomery to step down as inquiry head
column2: arguing that comments Gomery made to the press in December that were critical of Chrétien showed that he had prejudged the case and that his appointment of Bernard Roy
column3: one of the closest associates of Brian Mulroney
column4: as the commission’s lead lawyer indicated bias. (Roy was best man at Mulroney’s wedding
column5: later served as his chief of staff
column6: and currently works for the same law firm as Mulroney.)

column1: Chrétien concluded his testimony with a farcical piece of courtroom drama meant to underline his contempt for the proceedings. He answered Gomery’s quip that the government’s purchase of golf balls with his signature imprinted on them was “small-town cheap” by pulling from his pocket golf balls he had received from Presidents Bush and Clinton bearing their imprinted signatures
column2: as well as one produced for the law firm at which Mulroney and Bernard Roy now work.

column1: While Chrétien and the commission had their daggers drawn
column2: Justice Gomery and the commission’s lawyers gave Martin every opportunity to get out his message that he knew nothing of the details of the sponsorship program
column3: because he was preoccupied with his duties as finance minister
column4: and because Chrétien and his aides made sure that he had no role in managing the Quebec Liberal machine. Observing that it was “rather rare” for a prime minister to testify before a public inquiry
column5: government lawyer Sylvain Lussier concluded his questioning of Martin by asking
column6: “Is this an indication of how seriously you take the commission?”

column1: The press reaction to Chrétien’s and Martin’s testimony is more significant than the scripted lines they delivered during their respective appearances. While many newspaper columnists and editorial writers insisted that Chrétien has much to answer for
column2: there was a grudging admiration for his grit and political smarts.

column1: The press was all but unanimous that Martin should be taken at his word. But even as it exonerated the prime minister of all blame for the sponsorship program
column2: the press chastised him for his earnest
column3: long-winded answers and tied this to sharp criticisms of his failure to “show leadership.” By this
column4: they mean his reluctance to court unpopularity by taking decisions
column5: like signing Canada on to the US missile defence program
column6: strongly supported by the corporate and political elite.

column1: Only a short time ago
column2: the corporate elite was fixated on the need to replace Chrétien. Now
column3: his successor Martin is being derided as indecisive. According to the Economist
column4: Martin’s “faltering leadership has earned him the sobriquet of ‘Mr. Dithers’.”

column1: Yet the most powerful sections of the bourgeoisie have little confidence in the Conservatives under Harper as an alternative. They remain concerned about Harper’s strong identification with the demands of Western-based business and political interests for a greater share of political power and are aghast over his crude appeals to religious conservatism—he has said gay marriage could be the first step toward the Liberals sanctioning polygamy—and over his failure to vigorously promote business’s neo-liberal agenda or offer Martin the Conservatives’ support on missile defence.
Even the National Post dismissed Harper’s claim that Martin wasn’t ready to stand behind the Gomery inquiry
column2: when Chrétien sought to force the judge to step down
column3: as “posturing
column4: ” adding that Harper’s “Conservative Party remains very much a work in progress.”

column1: Canada’s corporate and political elite perceives itself to be falling behind in the global struggle for markets and profits and geo-political advantage and is increasingly frustrated at its inability to sideline public opposition to its drive for more tax cuts
column2: the gutting of Medicare and other public services
column3: the building up of the Canadian armed forces
column4: and full Canadian participation in a Fortress America. This malaise has found expression in the hullabaloo over the sponsorship scandal.

column1: The bourgeoisie
column2: however
column3: has numerous mechanisms
column4: economic and political
column5: to spur its political representatives rightward
column6: manipulate public opinion and deflect and smother opposition—not least the trade unions and the NDP.

column1: The opposition of working people remains inchoate and largely latent. It will only find coherent
column2: progressive political expression through the struggle for a new political orientation—the mobilization of the working class as an independent and international class against the profit system."	"[{'query': {'id': '1605046956333-3532832a3869c9ee'

Much of the money was funnelled through Liberal-friendly advertising firms. It is not uncommon for Canadian governments
column310: to steer government advertising and consultancy work to firms known to be friendly to the party in power. But in this case
column311: internal government audits found the program improperly managed
column312:
with financial records either nonexistent or replete with errors and gaps.

\n\n

A government study of contracts given to Le Groupe Polygone Editeurs
column313: which received $40 million in sponsorship money
column314:
said that there appeared to have been “systematic and egregious overcharging for what was delivered.” A subsequent investigation by Canada’s auditor-general found repeated instances of Groupe Polygone and other firms receiving large payments in return for little or no work. Criminal charges have been laid against several advertising company executives.

\n\n

There is little doubt some people criminally profited from the sponsorship program. There are also good grounds to believe that the program—whose ostensible purpose was to raise the profile of the federal government in Quebec and thereby counter the Quebec indépendantiste movement—was used to finance the Quebec wing of the Liberal Party. According to Alfonso Gagliano
column315: who for much of this period was both the minister responsible for the sponsorship program and the boss of the Quebec Liberal machine
column316: the Liberal Party was “not rich.” It
column318:
did receive substantial donations from many of the firms and executives of the firms that received sponsorship contracts from Gagliano’s Public Works Ministry or to which sponsorship work was subcontracted.

\n\n

That said
column319: the sponsorship scandal—the blaring headlines and feigned outrage of opposition politicians notwithstanding—is pretty much small potatoes. As the doyen of Canadian political journalism Peter C. Newman conceded
column320: patronage has always been integral to the functioning of Canada’s major political parties. “Patronage
column321: ” wrote Newman in a recent op-ed piece
column322: “is the udder of Canadian democracy. It has fuelled Canadian politics since Sir John A. Macdonald
column324:
accepted bribes from would-be builders of the CPR.”

\n\n

The enormous amount of air-time and ink the corporate media have devoted to the sponsorship scandal and the place it has taken in the official political debate stand in sharp contrast to the treatment accorded other cases of political corruption. Take
column326: the millions of dollars in questionable contracts that high-level operatives in the Ontario Tory government and Ontario Conservative Party were given by the province’s Crown-owned hydro companies between 1995 and 2003. As in the sponsorship scandal
column327:
many of the contracts called for little if any real work. Yet the press soon dropped the story.

\n\n

And what of the revelation that Karlheinz Schreiber
column328: a German-Canadian arms dealer whom the German government is seeking to extradite
column329: paid former Progressive Conservative Prime Minister Brian Mulroney $300
column331: in hotel rooms—shortly after he left office? Although Mulroney’s explanation—that the money was in return for the advice he gave Schreiber on a pasta-manufacturing scheme—is
column334:
few newspapers reported on Schreiber’s payments to Mulroney. None has pursued the story.

\n\n

If the sponsorship scandal has become such a major political issue
column335:
it is because it has served as a mechanism through which Canada’s corporate and political elite have fought out matters of leadership and policy direction.

\n\n

The neo-conservative National Post and the official opposition Canadian Alliance—now merged with the Tories in the new Conservative Party—have long-trumpeted allegations of waste and corruption in government spending. They have done so in order to discredit their Liberal rivals and
column337: with the aim of depicting government spending as out of control
column338: so as to bolster their crusade for tax cuts and for “getting government off the back of Canadians” through privatization and deregulation. In this they have been inspired
column340: by the US Republicans who used a trumped-up financial scandal
column342:
and then the Monica Lewinsky affair to destabilize the Clinton administration and ultimately to try to unseat Clinton.

Paul Martin and his supporters in the Liberal Party and sections of the ruling class who still view the Liberals as the party best able to govern in their interests—because of residual popular illusions in the Liberals’ being a party of the “people” and because of the Liberals’ commitment to a strong federal state—also made use of the sponsorship scandal and other allegations of impropriety in pushing for Chrétien to retire.

And since the release of the auditor-general’s damning report on the sponsorship program last February
column344: to say nothing of the pro-independence Bloc Québécois
column345: have all found it in their interest at various times to focus public attention on the sponsorship scandal
column346: so as to avoid discussion of their own records
column347:
programs and intentions.

\n\n

This choice of means is
column349: not without significance. There is great popular dissatisfaction with
column352: from the avowedly pro-big business Conservatives through the social democrats of the New Democratic Party
column353: because they have all been party to the assault on public and social services and trade union and democratic rights. Because there is no popular constituency for big business’s program of razing what remains of the welfare state
column354: gutting all regulatory restraints on capital
column355: and bringing Canada into a closer economic and geo-political partnership with Wall Street and Washington
column356:
big business and its political representatives have increasingly resorted to the politics of scandal and subterfuge and to nationalist and other noxious appeals in moulding and manipulating public opinion.

From Chrétien to Martin

Jean Chrétien
column357: in a lengthy opening statement before Justice Gomery’s inquiry
column358: made an impassioned defence of his government’s record
column359: arguing explicitly that his government had strengthened Canada and implicitly that he had well served the interests of Canadian big business. The Wall Street Journal
column361: had warned shortly after he came to office that Canada was being reduced to the status of a Third World country. But his government had taken decisive action to put federal finances in order. Boasted Chrétien
column362: “We had 10 great years when we turned it around
column365: in terms of socioeconomic and fiscal policy
column366: the Chrétien Liberal government was far and away the most right-wing federal government since the Great Depression. It slashed tens of billions from health care and other public services
column367: rewrote the rules governing Canada’s unemployment insurance program to deny benefits to the majority of the jobless
column369: once the annual budget deficit was eliminated
column371:
$100 billion program of corporate and personal income tax cuts skewed to benefit the rich and designed to ensure that the state lacked the resources to reinvest in public services.

\n\n

Nevertheless
column372: big business became increasingly dissatisfied with Chrétien
column373: especially after the coming to power of the Bush administration in 2001. Chrétien’s Trudeau-era Canadian nationalism
column375: his reluctance to give a massive
column376: multibillion-dollar permanent boost to the military budget
column377: and his failure to publicly promote privatization and deregulation
column378:
were all seen as inimical to big business’s interests.

\n\n

Under conditions where the bourgeoisie’s traditional alternate party of government
column380: had been reduced to a rump
column381:
the most powerful sections of Canadian business fixed on Martin—himself a multimillionaire businessman and Chrétien’s finance minister—as the best means of unseating Chrétien and shifting the government further right.

\n\n

Martin was thus egged on in his campaign to seize the leadership of the Liberal Party and prime ministership
column382: the first time a sitting prime minister was felled from within his own party. Although Martin did not directly raise the sponsorship issue during his campaign for the prime ministership
column383:
he certainly benefited by press suggestions that financial improprieties had taken place under Chrétien’s watch and alluded to the scandal with his promises of doing politics differently.

\n\n

What brought the sponsorship scandal to centre-stage was Martin’s decision to fan public outrage over the auditor-general’s report castigating the program. Rather than downplaying the report’s significance
column384: Martin declared himself mad as hell. He hailed the report’s author
column387: asserted that there must have been “political direction” behind the failure to follow normal government procedures in the awarding and administering of contracts
column388: fired Gagliano from his post as Canada’s ambassador to Denmark
column389:
and sacked several long-time Liberals from their posts as heads of various Crown Corporations.

\n\n

Invariably newspaper columnists have presented Martin’s response to the auditor-general’s report as a settling of accounts with Chrétien and his faction of the Liberal Party. Undoubtedly
column390: personal rivalries and power struggles were involved. But Martin’s decision to champion the sponsorship scandal was also rooted in his anxiousness to demonstrate to big business that his government was a new regime
column391:
not a continuation of the Chrétien Liberal government.

\n\n

Martin’s first actions on taking office all signalled a shift to the right. He announced an immediate review of all government spending and a freeze on recently announced expenditures. He stressed his intention to mend fences with the Bush administration and
column392: after an initial get-acquainted meeting with Bush
column393:
declared that any differences between the US and Canadian governments over the Iraq war were now history.

\n\n

The need to seek a popular mandate constrained Martin
column395: from fully satisfying business’s demand for a sharp shift to the right
column396: especially in the form of a new round of tax cuts
column397: the gutting of Canada’s Kyoto Accord commitments
column398: and a closer partnership with the US. He and his aides decided instead to amplify the sponsorship scandal
column401:
that a new team with different ideas was in power.

The ruse failed. Martin apparently believed the media hype about his being Canada’s most popular political leader and his unique bond with Canadians. But his trumpeting of the sponsorship scandal sent Liberal polling numbers into freefall.

The Conservatives and Bloc Québécois
column403: fastened onto the sponsorship scandal. Both parties made the purported fight against corruption in government the centrepiece of their campaigns for the June 30 federal election. For the Conservatives
column404:
the denunciations of Liberal corruption served as means of deflecting popular attention from their right-wing program and party leader Stephen Harper’s record as a neo-conservative ideologue.

\n\n

The election left the Liberals clinging to power
column405: more than 20 seats short of a majority of in the House of Commons. Moreover
column406: Martin’s room for maneuver was further reduced by the large increase in votes for parties that portray themselves as left-wing opponents of the two major parties
column408:
Bloc Québécois and Greens.

Chrétien and Martin before the commission

Chrétien was the first of the two Liberal Party leaders to appear before the Gomery Commission. He ceded nothing to his critics
column409: insisting that the sponsorship program had been an essential part of the federal government’s strategy to fight Quebec separatism
column410:
and made his disdain for the commission clear to all.

\n\n

Earlier Chrétien’s lawyers had pressed for Judge Gomery to step down as inquiry head
column411: arguing that comments Gomery made to the press in December that were critical of Chrétien showed that he had prejudged the case and that his appointment of Bernard Roy
column412: one of the closest associates of Brian Mulroney
column413: as the commission’s lead lawyer indicated bias. (Roy was best man at Mulroney’s wedding
column414: later served as his chief of staff
column415:
and currently works for the same law firm as Mulroney.)

\n\n

Chrétien concluded his testimony with a farcical piece of courtroom drama meant to underline his contempt for the proceedings. He answered Gomery’s quip that the government’s purchase of golf balls with his signature imprinted on them was “small-town cheap” by pulling from his pocket golf balls he had received from Presidents Bush and Clinton bearing their imprinted signatures
column416:
as well as one produced for the law firm at which Mulroney and Bernard Roy now work.

\n\n

While Chrétien and the commission had their daggers drawn
column417: Justice Gomery and the commission’s lawyers gave Martin every opportunity to get out his message that he knew nothing of the details of the sponsorship program
column418: because he was preoccupied with his duties as finance minister
column419: and because Chrétien and his aides made sure that he had no role in managing the Quebec Liberal machine. Observing that it was “rather rare” for a prime minister to testify before a public inquiry
column420: government lawyer Sylvain Lussier concluded his questioning of Martin by asking
column421:
“Is this an indication of how seriously you take the commission?”

\n\n

The press reaction to Chrétien’s and Martin’s testimony is more significant than the scripted lines they delivered during their respective appearances. While many newspaper columnists and editorial writers insisted that Chrétien has much to answer for
column422:
there was a grudging admiration for his grit and political smarts.

\n\n

The press was all but unanimous that Martin should be taken at his word. But even as it exonerated the prime minister of all blame for the sponsorship program
column423: the press chastised him for his earnest
column424: long-winded answers and tied this to sharp criticisms of his failure to “show leadership.” By this
column425: they mean his reluctance to court unpopularity by taking decisions
column426: like signing Canada on to the US missile defence program
column427:
strongly supported by the corporate and political elite.

\n\n

Only a short time ago
column428: the corporate elite was fixated on the need to replace Chrétien. Now
column429: his successor Martin is being derided as indecisive. According to the Economist
column430:
Martin’s “faltering leadership has earned him the sobriquet of ‘Mr. Dithers’.”

Yet the most powerful sections of the bourgeoisie have little confidence in the Conservatives under Harper as an alternative. They remain concerned about Harper’s strong identification with the demands of Western-based business and political interests for a greater share of political power and are aghast over his crude appeals to religious conservatism—he has said gay marriage could be the first step toward the Liberals sanctioning polygamy—and over his failure to vigorously promote business’s neo-liberal agenda or offer Martin the Conservatives’ support on missile defence.

Even the National Post dismissed Harper’s claim that Martin wasn’t ready to stand behind the Gomery inquiry
column431: when Chrétien sought to force the judge to step down
column433:
” adding that Harper’s “Conservative Party remains very much a work in progress.”

\n\n

Canada’s corporate and political elite perceives itself to be falling behind in the global struggle for markets and profits and geo-political advantage and is increasingly frustrated at its inability to sideline public opposition to its drive for more tax cuts
column434: the gutting of Medicare and other public services
column435: the building up of the Canadian armed forces
column436:
and full Canadian participation in a Fortress America. This malaise has found expression in the hullabaloo over the sponsorship scandal.

\n\n

The bourgeoisie
column440: to spur its political representatives rightward
column441:
manipulate public opinion and deflect and smother opposition—not least the trade unions and the NDP.

\n\n

The opposition of working people remains inchoate and largely latent. It will only find coherent
column442:
progressive political expression through the struggle for a new political orientation—the mobilization of the working class as an independent and international class against the profit system.

\n\n'

column1: A recent survey among 66 central banks by the Bank for International Settlements shows that more than 80% are working on central bank digital currencies (CBDCs). The European Central Bank is one of them.
Not because we want to keep up with fashionable trends

column1: We are technology neutral. But if our customers

column1: Although cash often gets a bad press

column1: Part of ECB mandate to be ready for change

One implication of financial technological innovation could be an increasingly cashless economy in which people may no longer be able to hold risk-free central bank money. Reliable access to money would then hinge on the stability and efficiency of private retail infrastructures. And trust in money itself would rely on trust in the intermediaries that issue private money.
This is one reason why central banks keep fully up to speed on financial technological developments. After all
column2: providing safe money and a reliable means of payment have been an integral part of the mandate and core business of central banks since their very inception. The ECB is no exception.

column1: So we should be looking ahead and consider whether
column2: in the future
column3: central banks will need to provide the public with some form of digital currency. While electronic payments are already crowding out the use of cash in some countries
column4: whose currencies seem less attractive than the euro
column5: there is no such trend away from cash in the euro area.

column1: Some 76% of all transactions in the euro area are carried out in cash
column2: amounting to more than half of the total value of all payments. The demand for cash in the euro area currently outstrips the rate of nominal GDP growth.

column1: In crisis times
column2: the demand for cash surges even higher. At mid-March this year
column3: the weekly increase in the value of banknotes in circulation almost reached the historical peak of €19 billion.

column1: The ECB’s debate on CBDCs is therefore mainly analytical. Whether and when it becomes more of a policy debate will largely depend on the preferences of households.
We are always willing to innovate in the form of money and payment services that we provide. If
column2: for instance
column3: people voiced a preference tomorrow for plastic or polymer banknotes rather than the traditional paper ones
column4: we would happily accommodate them.

column1: In the same vein

column1: The lack of a concrete “business case” for a CBDC at present should and does not stop us from seriously exploring the optimal design of a CBDC so that we will be well prepared should we ever take a policy decision to issue a digital currency. To this end

column1: Let me give you a preview of our deliberations

column251: provide additional services to those offered by central banks. Such services could include paying bills
column252:
or cross-selling financial insurance products.

\n\n

Otherwise – even in the absence of a crisis – a readily convertible CBDC could crowd out bank deposits
column253:
leading to the disintermediation of the banking sector. This could have far-reaching implications for the structure of the financial system and for the ability of central banks to perform their core tasks and ensure that their monetary policy is transmitted to the real economy.

\n\n

If the central bank were to take retail deposits
column254: it might also have to provide loans
column255: with all the ensuing consequences. The central bank would need to launch customer-facing business lines. Deposit and lending facilities would also require the central bank to take on the burden of regulatory compliance in areas such as anti-money laundering
column256:
consumer protection and confidentiality.

\n\n

Some argue that this may reinforce monetary sovereignty
column257:
as disintermediation would make the financial system safer and reduce the moral hazard of banks by diminishing their role in money creation.

\n\n

But disintermediation would be economically inefficient and legally untenable. The EU Treaty provides for the ECB to operate in an open market economy
column258:
essentially reflecting a policy choice in favour of decentralised market decisions on the optimal allocation of resources.

\n\n

Historical cases of economy-wide resource allocation by central banks are hardly models of efficiency or good service. Furthermore
column259:
a retail CBDC would create a disproportionate concentration of power in the central bank.

These potentially highly adverse effects on the financial system would appear to outweigh the benefits envisaged by the introduction of a retail CBDC.

What
column261:
could be done to mitigate the impact of a CBDC on the financial system?

One option could be to remunerate CBDC at below-market rates in order to create incentives for non-banks to rely more on market-based alternatives rather than on central bank deposits.

The drawback would be that
column263: it may become necessary to apply highly negative rates
column264:
which could generate criticism from the public and substantially undermine public confidence in the central bank as well as in the basic values of saving which underlie our societies.

\n\n

Another option is a tiered remuneration system. In line with the functions of money
column265: the first tier couldserve as a means of payment. The central bank would have to refrain from setting a lower or a negative interest rate in order to keep a CBDC attractive to the public as a means of payment. While the second tier could serve as a store of value
column266:
the central banks could discourage people from using it as such by setting unattractive interest rates.

\n\n

However
column267:
such schemes should draw from the experience of multiple exchange rate regimes. And the repercussions of the intentional use of such schemes need to be subjected to an additional comprehensive investigation.

\n\n

So we have plenty of questions on CBDC to discuss. In monitoring the evolution and uses of technology
column268:
the ECB respects technological neutrality. We do not serve technology – technology serves us. We will only introduce a digital currency if we become firmly convinced that it is both necessary and proportionate to fulfil our tasks in ensuring the stability of our currency.

\n\n

In the meantime
column269: we take a keen interest in digital innovation and in the changing expectations of money users
column270: and we are refining our thinking on CBDC – both within the ECB
column271:
the Eurosystem and in the international central banking community. CBDC design choices are not merely technical questions. They have policy and legal implications. This is why we are devoting so much attention to every detail.

\n\n

If and when the time comes
column272:
we want to be ready – and we will be ready.

\n\n'

They have very little energy left to actually focus on improving their financial crime-fighting abilities. The software they’re using is similar
column169: focused almost wholly on compliance
column170:
not crime-fighting”.

\n\n

That is where Salv wants to step in
column171:
and Tamkivi says the main difference between the startup’s AML software and other existing solutions is a much greater emphasis on crime-fighting rather than a box-ticking compliance exercise.

\n\n

“We’re aiming to create a transformation similar to what’s happened in virus scanning
column172: ” he says. “10-15 years ago virus scanners on everyone’s PCs were an enormous hassle
column173: consumed tons of resources and stopped you from getting work done. The same is true in financial institutions today. They’re using outdated
column174: heavy software and processes to handle AML. But today
column175: virus scanning still happens
column176: but nobody’s worried about it. It happens in the background
column177:
with few resources. We’ll do the same in the AML world”.

\n\n

In addition
column178: the Salv CEO claims that the company’s software is faster than competitors’ offerings
column179: both in terms of set up time and integration
column180:
and making changes to the rules the system adheres to.

\n\n

“Our system
column181: by contrast
column182: takes a month or less to set up and minutes to modify the rules
column183: ” he says. “As a result
column184: our customers can take everything they learn today from new criminal patterns
column185: encode it in automated rules tomorrow
column186:
and repeat that cycle every day to protect their bank. Moving fast is the only way to keep up with the innovative organised criminals moving millions or billions around the world”.

\n\n

To that end
column187: Salv already counts Estonian bank LHV as its first customer. “They offer a full suite of banking products across Estonia
column188: ” says Tamkivi. “They’re also active in London
column189: in particular
column190:
supporting fintechs. We have another couple of customers in the Lithuanian fintech scene. One of those is DeVere e-Money” .

\n\n

More generally
column191: Salv’s product is said to be suitable for Tier 2 and Tier 3 banks
column192:
as well as regulated fintechs and challenger banks.

\n\n

Meanwhile
column193: the business model is straightforward enough. Salv charges a monthly subscription
column194:
while the price varies based on the number of active customers a bank or fintech has.

\n\n

WASHINGTON – The U.S. Department of the Treasury today designated four members of Hizballah’s leadership responsible for operations throughout the Middle East
column217: further exposing Hizballah’s pernicious activities that reach beyond the borders of Lebanon. \xa0These designations include senior members of Hizballah responsible for activities ranging from assisting fighters from Iraq to support the Assad regime in Syria
column218: to making payments to various factions within Yemen
column219: and to military leaders responsible for terrorist operations in Egypt
column220: Jordan
column221: Turkey
column222: Cyprus
column223: Israel
column224: the Palestinian territories
column225:
and Iraq.

\n\n

Belying Hizballah’s claim to be a domestic Lebanese “resistance” organization
column226: its expansive global network seeks to extend its malign influence
column227: and the influence of Hizballah’s patron Iran
column228:
throughout the Middle East and beyond. \xa0The Treasury Department will continue to combat Hizballah’s terrorist activity inside and outside Lebanon with all available tools and will continue to work with partners around the world to make it clear that Hizballah’s militant and extremist activities should not be tolerated by any nation.

\n\n

“Whether ferrying foreign fighters to the front lines of the Syrian civil war or inserting clandestine operatives in Europe
column229: the Middle East
column230: and elsewhere
column231: Hizballah remains a significant global terrorist threat
column232: ” said Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence David S. Cohen. \xa0“So long as Hizballah spreads instability
column233: conducts terrorist attacks and engages in criminal and illicit activities around the world
column234: we will continue to sanction Hizballah’s operatives
column236:
wherever they may be found.”

\n\n

column237: which targets terrorists and their supporters for acting for
column238: or on behalf of Hizballah. \xa0U.S. persons are generally prohibited from engaging in any transactions with the individuals designated today

and any assets of those designees subject to U.S. jurisdiction are frozen.

column247: Harb was given responsibility for overseeing work of the Islamic Resistance
column248: including assisting with the smuggling of Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad operatives from Syria into the West Bank via Jordan. \xa0By late 2003
column249: Harb was head of the Syrian/Jordan/Israel/Egypt operations unit
column250:
which was subordinate to Hizballah’s Islamic Jihad council.

column251: Harb served as Hizballah’s chief of military liaison with the Palestinian factions and Iran

'articleBodyRaw': '

Man ran two-year drug smuggling operation from three prisons

Published
7 September

A prisoner ran a two-year-long drug smuggling operation from three Scottish jails by phone and mail
column51:
a court has heard.

Craig Sutton
column53: carried out the operation while he was an inmate at HMP Perth
column54: HMP Edinburgh
column55:
and HMP Addiewell in West Lothian.

The offences only came to light when Sutton\'s cell at HMP Addiewell was searched after a fire alarm went off in a neighbouring cell.

He will be sentenced in October.

Co-accused Natalie Williamson
column57: from Renfrew
column58: who admitted allowing her bank account to be used to deposit £30
column59:
000 of criminal money will be sentenced at the same time.

The High Court in Glasgow was told the offences took place between February 2015 and July 2017.

Letters seized

Prosecutor Mark McGuire said an initial search of Sutton\'s cell revealed heroin
column60: drug paraphernalia
column61:
and a suspected tick list.

A subsequent full search found dozens of letters addressed to Sutton from other prisoners.

There was also an unsent letter written by Sutton in which he set out his plan to smuggle drugs into prison.

Police also seized recordings of all telephone calls made or received by Sutton since he was jailed in 2014.

Mr McGuire said: ""Those recordings included frequent discussions between the accused Sutton and the accused Williamson during which Sutton made frequent reference to his trafficking in heroin and ecstasy inside and outside of the prison estate.

""Discussions also took place between the two regarding the use of Williamson\'s bank account to receive the money owed to Sutton for drugs.""

Prisons investigation

Judge Lord Burns asked Mr McGuire if there had been a time when the letters were examined in the prison.

Mr McGuire said: ""There are two possibilities - the letters and phone recordings were monitored and nothing was done
column62:
or they were not monitored.""

Lord Burns said: ""It is of concern an operation involving a number of prisons and nothing was done about it.""

He ordered the prosecutor to investigate.

Sutton
column63: who appeared in court via a video link
column64:
was remanded in custody and Williamson was granted bail.

He said Cyprus is working closely with foreign supervisory authorities from the EU and the U.S. to ensure that financial sector legislation is fully in line with international best practices.

Some of the key reforms include obligatory face-to-face meetings between banks and account owners and strong regulations on disclosing the individual who is the ultimate holder of a bank account.

Earlier this year

Cyprus also introduced new shell company regulations that prohibit Cypriot banks from doing business with entities that are identified as shell companies.
