The call by Rachel Reeves
column2: the Labour chair of the business select committee
column3: and Frank Field
column4: the Labour head of the work and pensions select committee
column5: comes as the Conservative-led Treasury select committee plans to hold meetings around the country to examine the impact of debt on individuals and households.

column1: “ Debt is a huge emotional burden for people
column2: ” said Nicky Morgan
column3: the Conservative MP who chairs the Treasury select committee. She added that “unstable personal finances” often emerged as problems raised by her constituents in Loughborough.

column1: The £200bn of debt amassed on credit cards
column2: personal loans and car deals is now at the same level it reached before the 2008 financial crisis and there are fears that rises in interest rates could put more households under pressure. Mark Carney
column3: the governor of the Bank of England
column4: warned on Monday that interest rates were likely to rise in response to rising inflation and skills shortages brought on by Brexit that will increase pressure on wages.

column1: Field said people in his Birkenhead constituency on the Wirral were being pushed into destitution by the actions of loan sharks and finance companies that heaped extra pain on low income households with sky-high interest charges.
He said: “We need a commission to assess the current situation. There are so many moving parts that a proper investigation goes beyond the remit of any single committee.”
According to the Money Advice Service
column2: there are now 8.3 million people in the UK with problem debts while the government’s official economic forecaster
column3: the Office for Budget Responsibility
column4: has predicted that unsecured consumer debt – which includes loans
column5: credit cards
column6: overdrafts and car financing – will soar as a proportion of national income over the next four years back above its previous peak in 2007.

column1: Reeves
column2: Labour MP for Leeds West – who was speaking in a personal capacity – said she was shocked at the sharp rise in borrowing to finance new car purchases and soaring credit card debts.

column1: “It is the government’s responsibility to understand the extent of the issue and who is the worst affected
column2: ” she said.

column1: “When you have people right up the income scale being told by the banks not to worry that they can’t afford the price of a car
column2: just borrow the money anyway
column3: ” Reeves said.

column1: Andrew Bailey
column2: the chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority
column3: on Monday called on the government to help craft a sustainable solution to enable vulnerable borrowers to obtain finance.

column1: Reeves and Field said they were concerned that there were large gaps in the remits of the regulators given responsibility for monitoring Britain’s debts.
Neither the Bank of England
column2: which monitors the banking sector
column3: the FCA nor the OBR has an overarching responsibility to report to government about the UK’s debt position.

column1: Reeves said the financial services industry needed to be more transparent about the level of indebtedness and subprime lending.

Field said regulators need to be more explicit about the extent of the damage to households and the economy from a shock that could be caused by an increase in unemployment or increased interest rates.
The detail of the Treasury select committee inquiry is still being worked out but Morgan said her ambition was take evidence “not just sitting in London”.
When she was standing to become chair of the committee after the election
column2: Morgan had flagged the issue of household debt as one of the areas she felt needed closer examination. She wanted to look at “what it is about our households that accumulate debt”.

column1: The aim was to “add something intelligent to the policy debate”
column2: said Morgan.

column1: A Treasury spokeswoman said the government was focused on supporting the growth of secure and better-paid jobs as the route out of debt. The increase in full-time jobs in the past two years and a higher minimum wage meant that fewer people were coping with low and erratic wages. She added that tighter rules on the financial services industry provided consumers with greater protection than before the 2008 crash.
She said: “We have fundamentally reformed the consumer credit market so that the Financial Conduct Authority now [has] robust powers to help consumers
column2: such as protecting 760
column3: 0000 people with the new cap on payday loans. A record number of people are in work and we are helping them keep more of what they earn by cutting taxes and raising the ‘national living wage’.”

column1: John McDonnell
column2: the shadow chancellor
column3: said: “Labour is deeply worried by the concerns raised by the Bank of England over the high levels of personal debt.”

column1: A senior Bank of England official
column2: Alex Brazier
column3: recently told banks
column4: credit card companies and car loan providers that they risked fresh action against reckless lending and warned of a looming “spiral of complacency” about mounting consumer debt. He added: “Household debt – like most things that are good in moderation – can be dangerous in excess.”

column1: McDonnell said: “We believe this is an area where there is a need for government intervention
column2: and we will be bring forward policy proposals on this matter.

column1: “The last seven years has seen the Tories fail to tackle the fall in wages
column2: which has also witnessed a surge in unsecured lending; as many families have been forced into debt in order to just make ends meet.”

column1: Vince Cable
column2: the Liberal Democrat leader
column3: also supported calls for a public inquiry
column4: adding that it would prove futile if it ignores “an economically destructive extreme Brexit that will push the indebted over the edge”.

column1: Cable added: “The government must also immediately implement its manifesto commitment to introduce a ‘breathing space’ for people with problematic debt

Your Integrity Policy Matters

Mexico’s General Law of Administrative Accountability
column111: set to go into effect next week
column112: is the final part of a historic package of far-reaching anti-corruption laws
column113: dubbed the National Anti-Corruption System
column114: that were passed last year. Taken as a whole
column115:
the National Anti-Corruption System will have far-flung consequences for those doing business in Mexico and will expand the scope of potential anti-corruption enforcement.\xa0

\n\n

On\xa0July 19
column117: Mexico’s General Law of Administrative Accountability will go into effect. It is the final part of a historic package of far-reaching anti-corruption laws
column118: dubbed the National Anti-Corruption System
column119: that were passed last year. Taken as a whole
column120:
the National Anti-Corruption System will have far-flung consequences for those doing business in Mexico or considering doing business in Mexico.

\n\n

When the General Law of Administrative Accountability goes into effect
column121: it will expand the scope of potential anti-corruption enforcement. Whereas the 2012 Public Contracting Anti-Corruption Law – the law repealed and replaced by the General Law of Administrative Accountability – was limited to the federal procurement space
column122:
the new law’s prohibitions apply to more conduct and in a wider business context.

\n\n

First and foremost
column123: the new law broadly defines prohibited “bribery” as: (1) where a private party offers or gives money or another gift to a public official to cause the official to do or refrain from doing any act related to the official’s functions; or (2) where a public official
column124: directly or indirectly
column125: solicits or receives for himself or another person
column126: money or another gift in exchange for doing or refraining from doing any act related to the official’s functions. In turn
column127: “public official” is broadly defined as any individual that has employment
column128: a position
column129:
or a charge of any type in the Mexican government; government majority-owned companies; public trusts; or that handles federal economic resources.

\n\n

Other notable prohibitions under the new law include: using or attempting to use influence or economic or political power on a public official in order to obtain a benefit or advantage or to damage any person; using false information during an administrative proceeding in order to obtain an authorization
column130: benefit or advantage
column131: or to damage any person; taking joint action with other private parties to obtain a benefit or advantage in a federal
column132: state or municipal public procurement process; participating in administrative proceedings after being prohibited from doing so due to prior misconduct; misusing public resources (material
column133: human
column134:
or financial); and hiring current or former government officials with privileged information for competitive advantage.

\n\n

The new law applies to public servants and private parties
column135: including both legal entities and individuals. This includes companies in Mexico and those based outside of Mexico
column136: their affiliates and their officers who do business in Mexico and have direct or indirect contacts with Mexican officials. Further
column137:
a legal entity may be liable for offenses committed by its employees or third parties acting on behalf of the entity in order to obtain benefits for the entity.

\n\n

Penalties for violating the new law can be severe. Individuals and companies face sanctions up to twice the amount of any acquired benefits
column138: compensatory and/or punitive damages and/or a temporary ban on participating in procurement
column139: leases
column140: services or state-owned projects (e.g.
column141:
projects with Pemex). Companies further face the brand new penalties of a temporary suspension of operations or dissolution.

\n\n

However
column142: Mexico’s new law also provides that sanctions shall be mitigated by 50-70 percent where a company self-reports past or ongoing misconduct and has implemented and enforced an adequate “Integrity Policy.” An “Integrity Policy” is defined to include
column143: at a minimum: (1) a document setting forth the functions and responsibilities of each of the company’s areas
column144:
the leadership throughout the company and a clear chain of command; (2) a code of conduct with enforcement protocol; (3) control and audit systems that regularly supervise standards of compliance within the organization; (4) internal whistleblower and reporting systems that allow for appropriate reporting to enforcement authorities and disciplinary procedures for employees acting contrary to company policy or Mexican law; and (5) human resources policies for preventing the hiring of persons that may pose compliance risks to the organization.

\n\n

Companies doing business or seeking to do business in Mexico should take action to inform themselves of the legal implications of the National Anti-Corruption System. This includes developing
column145: implementing
column146:
enforcing and documenting an Integrity Policy that applies many of the risk assessment-based procedures and controls that are the hallmarks of a modern and effective compliance program.

Burney refers to Mulroney as “the patriarch of the Conservative party

In recent interviews
column581: Mulroney too has drawn a line

emphasizing his government’s record of increasing the flow of immigrants and refugees into the country. He told Power & Politics of his “firm belief that Canada and other democracies only prosper with great waves of immigration\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009Anything that varies from what I just said should be unacceptable.”

\n

Mulroney’s association with the current Conservatives is complex. He avidly supported his daughter Caroline Mulroney’s run for leadership of the Ontario Conservatives—and the creation of a possible Mulroney political dynasty. In Patrick Brown’s 2018 book Takedown: The Attempted Political Assassination of Patrick Brown
column583: the deposed Ontario Conservative leader reveals that Mulroney promised Brown a place “at the centre” of his daughter’s government if he swung his organizational clout to her campaign for leader—and then for premier. Brown didn’t. Caroline Mulroney
column585:
lost the leadership race but won a seat and was named attorney general in the Doug Ford government.

Tensions are also said to exist between Andrew Scheer’s team and Mulroney. Scheer spokesperson Daniel Schow is vague when asked about the relationship: “They’ve spoken. They have friends in common. They’re both Conservative politicians.” Mulroney will be diplomatically quiet during the federal election
column586: his spokesperson Sears predicts: “No one expects him to be completely silent. But I think he’ll be more circumspect and less frequent.” Speaking up is a delicate matter
column587: given his daughter’s place in the Ford government. “He is used as a club to beat her with by the Liberals and New Dems
column588: ” Sears says. (Friends say Mulroney is not happy about Butt’s tweets that criticize his daughter’s rejection of a carbon tax.) Sears laments Canada’s treatment of retired politicians: “I find it so distressing that when we have a former leader pass from the stage we put them on the iceberg and let them float gently out to sea.” In a conversation held before Canadian ambassador to China John McCallum’s exit
column589: Sears proposes that Mulroney’s skill set could be useful in the current standoff with China. “[Jean] Chrétien and Brian have forgotten more about Canada-China relations than these kids would know in the next 10 years
column590: ” he says. “Why not call either of them to make a discreet visit to Beijing to express our sympathies for the unhappiness this situation has caused the both of us and say
column591: ‘Are there any messages you want to convey privately?’\u2009” Using former U.S. presidents to broker such matters is a time-honoured American trick. It’s telling of the political moment
column593:
that it’s an idea not unworthy of consideration.

400 journalists from 88 countries have been investigating the documents.

\n\n

Leaked documents showed Dubai-based Gunes General Trading
column156: which is alleged by the U.S. prosecutors of being a part of a network controlled by Zarrab that conducted hundreds of millions of dollars’ worth of transactions on behalf of the Iranian government and other Iranian entities that were barred under U.S. sanctions
column157:
processed $142m in suspicious transactions through the UAE financial system in 2011 and 2012.

\n\n

The activity was flagged by a British bank
column158: but the firm was able to continue using local financial institutions
column159:
BBC reported.

Suspicious transactions by Gunes General Trading

Banks based in the UAE rely on big U.S.-based banks to monitor and approve their US dollar payments – a service known as “correspondent banking.”

Correspondent banks are required to alert authorities to potential instances of criminal activity
column160: such as money laundering or terrorist financing
column161:
by filing a document known as a suspicious activity report (SAR).

Among the FinCEN files is an SAR that shows the New York branch of Standard Chartered Bank contacted the Central Bank of the UAE in 2012 after noticing hundreds of suspicious transactions by Gunes General Trading. The reports did not say any of this activity was linked to sanctions evasion by Iran.

SARs are a way to alert government regulators and law enforcement to irregular activity that should be investigated
column162:
although they are not necessarily evidence of wrongdoing.

The central bank told Standard Chartered that “the case has been passed on to law enforcement authorities” and that “accounts were closed in September 2011.”

But Standard Chartered flagged that the company was able to “continue its suspicious activity” by “utilizing various accounts that [it] maintains with other banks.”

In fact
column163: the central bank failed to stop Gunes General Trading using two other accounts with two UAE state-owned banks – Rakbank
column164: the national bank of the northern emirate Ras al-Khaimah
column165:
and the National Bank of Dubai (NBD).

\n\n

The FinCEN files show Gunes General Trading was able to process a further $108m of transactions flagged as suspicious until September 2012
column166:
the majority of them through Rakbank.

\n\n

In April 2013
column167: the U.S. Bank of New York Mellon filed a SAR saying that following a U.S. government inquiry into Gunes General Trading
column168:
it believed the company was conducting transactions in a manner designed to evade sanctions against Iran.

\n\n

The FinCEN Files also suggest that Deutsche Bank continued to move money for people and companies deemed suspicious
column169: as indicated by SAR filings from the bank
column170: after it received a $258 million fine for violating U.S. sanctions in 2015
column171:
Deutsche Welle reported.

\n\n

Deutsche Bank’s U.S. affiliate
column172: Deutsche Bank Trust Company Americas (TCA)
column173: submitted an SAR about a company with close ties to Zarrab to FinCEN in March 2017. The report states that the company
column174: Nadir Döviz
column175: which is involved in the gold trade
column176:
had more than $28 million transferred in its name.

Turkey ‘a high-risk country’

Deutsche Bank TCA filed its SAR because Nadir Döviz was being investigated for its involvement in a money-laundering scheme. The document says the transactions occurred between March 2016 and February 2017.

In its report
column177: Deutsche Bank stated that the suspicious activities were intra-company payments dispersed between several Turkish banks. “This SAR is being filed because the transactions originated from a high-risk country [Turkey]
column178: there were multiple large
column179: round dollar transactions
column180: and no commercial purpose was identified through the transaction details
column181:
” it reads.

\n\n

One of these suspicious transactions was for $1.5 million from Nadir Döviz in Turkey to Nadir Gold in Dubai on Sept. 12
column182:
2016. No reason was provided for the transfer.

\n\n

Upon receiving a catalogue of detailed questions from ICIJ
column183: a spokesman for Deutsche Bank said the information contained in the files is “not new information to us or our regulators” and that these issues date back to the years prior to 2016
column184:
adding that Deutsche Bank is “a different bank now.”

\n\n

In his statement from Sept. 9
column185: the spokesman emphasized: “We acknowledged past weaknesses in our control environment
column186: we apologized for this and accepted our respective fines. Most importantly: We learned from our mistakes
column187: systematically tackled the issues and made changes to our business perimeter
column188: our controls
column189:
and our personnel.”

The dates of the recorded Suspicious Activity Reports raise questions about how much Deutsche Bank knew about Döviz’s connection to Zarrab and the Turkish trader’s involvement in what turned out to be a gold for oil scheme to circumvent sanctions against Iran.

Reza Zarrab’s billion-dollar scheme

When Iranian banks were cut off from the global SWIFT transaction system
column190:
the country’s companies could no longer use international banking transfers to receive payment for oil and gas exports.

\n\n

To get around the ban
column191:
Iran began collecting gold as payments instead. Reza Zarrab played a key role in this billion-dollar scheme to help Iran evade sanctions.

\n\n

Zarrab was first indicted and arrested in December 2013 in Turkey
column192: as part of a larger corruption investigation aimed at ministers in the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) government. Among the charges directed at him were bribing ministers
column193:
money laundering and gold smuggling.

\n\n

According to a report by Turkish prosecutors at the time
column194: Zarrab used Nadir Döviz for buying gold. Zarrab’s bagman Adem Karahan later told Turkish daily<em> Cumhuriyet
column195:
that he was a cash courier for money going from Dubai to Turkey and from Dubai to Iran.

\n\n

One of the companies he received money from was Nadir Gold LLC
column196:
a subsidiary of Nadir Döviz in Dubai. It is precisely these two companies that Deutsche Bank lists in its March 2017 Suspicious Activity Report to FinCEN.

\n\n

At the time
column197: the administration of President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan refuted all allegations against Zarrab and likened the investigation to a coup attempt
column198: purging and arresting the prosecutors who initiated it. After two and a half months in prison
column199:
Zarrab was released.

\n\n

In March 2016 Zarrab was arrested again
column200: this time in the U.S. while on route to Disney World with his family. U.S. authorities accused him of money laundering
column201:
fraud and helping the Iranian government to evade the economic sanctions.

He pleaded guilty and later testified as a protected star witness in a trial against a manager of Turkey’s Halkbank.

During this trial in November 2017
column202: Zarrab claimed that Turkish government officials
column203: including Erdoğan
column204:
had allowed Halkbank to create a complex web of shell companies and sham transactions in gold to help Iran get around U.S. sanctions.

\n\n'

National Conference president Farooq Abdullah appeared before the Enforcement Directorate on Wednesday
column49: second time this week
column50:
for questioning in connection with a money laundering probe into an alleged multi-crore scam in the Jammu and Kashmir Cricket Association (JKCA).

The 82-year-old former chief minister of Jammu and Kashmir was questioned for over six hours on October 19 in the case.

After the questioning on Monday
column51:
Abdullah had said he was not worried and would cooperate in the probe.

\n\n

The last round of questioning took place four days after Jammu and Kashmir\'s mainstream political parties
column52: including the NC and the PDP
column53:
met at Abdullah's residence and formed the People's Alliance for 'Gupkar Declaration'.

ED officials said Abdullah's statement will be recorded under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) as in the past. He was questioned for the first time in July last year in Chandigarh.

The ED is understood to be questioning Abdullah about his role and decisions taken when the alleged fraud took place in the association when he was the JKCA president.

The agency's case is based on an FIR filed by the CBI
column54: which booked former JKCA office-bearers
column55:
including general secretary Mohammed Saleem Khan and former treasurer Ahsan Ahmad Mirza.

\n\n

The CBI had also filed a charge sheet in 2018 against Abdullah

column57:
Mirza as well as former JKCA treasurer Mir Manzoor Gazanffer Ali and former accountants Bashir Ahmad Misgar and Gulzar Ahmad Beigh for the ""misappropriation of JKCA funds amounting to Rs 43.69 crore"" from grants given by the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) to promote the sport in the erstwhile state between 2002 and 2011.

In brief

The new corporate liability provision under Section 17A of the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission Act 2009 (“Section 17A“) has come into force on 1 June 2020. As highlighted in our earlier client alert (see Link)
column50: a company may be held criminally liable under this new provision for acts of bribery committed by its directors
column51:
employees or other associated persons.\xa0 The only defence available is for the company to prove that it has put in place adequate procedures designed to prevent these corrupt acts.

\n\n

This new corporate liability provision applies not only to Malaysian companies
column52:
but also to foreign companies with businesses in Malaysia.

Impact on Foreign Companies

The new Section 17A applies to all foreign companies and partnerships which carry on businesses in Malaysia. Although the Act is silent as to what amounts to “carrying out business” in Malaysia
column53:
it is likely that a foreign entity will fall within the ambit of Section 17A if it carries on business in Malaysia through an agent or intermediary such as a distributor or reseller and/or through a subsidiary.

The following are examples of two scenarios where a foreign company may be exposed to liability under Section 17A:

  1. Foreign company’s employees or agents pay a bribe in Malaysia

A foreign company may be liable for an offence under Section 17A of the Act if its employees
column54:
agents or persons associated with it bribes or attempts to give a bribe in Malaysia to obtain or retain business or business advantage for the company.

  1. Foreign company’s subsidiary pays a bribe in Malaysia

A foreign company may also be liable if its subsidiary bribes or attempts to give a bribe in Malaysia to obtain or retain business or business advantage. This is illustrated in the first prosecution under the UK Bribery Act 2020 in the case of R v Sweett Group plc (“Sweett“) (unreported)(2015)
column55: whereby a subsidiary of Sweett paid a bribe in the Middle East to secure a project. Notwithstanding that
column56: the subsidiary engaged in the bribery without the involvement or knowledge of its parent company and that the contract was awarded to the subsidiary
column57:
the judge took into account the fact that the subsidiary was not autonomous but was effectively operated by Sweett as a division in the Middle East.

\n\n

For completeness
column58: we wish to highlight that liability may not accrue through simple corporate ownership or investment
column59:
or through the payment of dividends or provision of loans by a subsidiary to its parents. The degree of control of the Malaysian subsidiary will be a relevant factor whether liability is extended to a foreign holding company under Section 17A.

Action to consider

The penalties arising from liability under Section 17A is a fine not less than 10 times the value of the bribe or MYR 1 million (whichever is higher) and/or imprisonment of a term not exceeding 20 years.

In light of this
column60:
foreign companies with businesses in Malaysia should take steps to assess their risk and to consider putting in place the required adequate procedures which is the only defence available for corporates arising from liability under Section 17A. Please refer to our previous client alert here on how to comply with the requisite adequate procedures under Section 17A.

\n\n'

It was 2013 and officers at the Estonian branch of Danske Bank were beginning to realise they had taken on some very unpleasant customers. After a tipoff
column2: a member of staff had travelled to Moscow and started asking questions. The team was trying to trace the identity of people hiding behind anonymous corporate vehicles
column3: which had opened accounts and were now using them to transfer huge sums of money. That was when its staff began to receive anonymous threats. “This bank will sink
column4: ” one caller warned.

column1: Today
column2: Danske is still very much in business
column3: but its chief executive
column4: Thomas Borgen
column5: has resigned. He fell on his sword after a report produced by lawyers for his board
column7: revealed the full extent of problems at the Estonian branch. It had thousands of suspicious customers
column8: responsible for €200bn (£180bn) of transactions over a nine-year period. The realisation is dawning that what has been uncovered is probably the largest ever money-laundering scandal in history.

column1: “Europe has a major money-laundering problem
column2: ” said anti-corruption expert Nienke Palstra
column3: at campaign group Global Witness. “Until we see senior executives held fully accountable for criminal wrongdoing and serious fines for the banks involved
column4: this kind of scandal will continue for decades to come.”

column1: Regulators and law enforcement agencies are slowly beginning to respond. Britain’s National Crime Agency (NCA) has confirmed it is investigating an anonymous corporate vehicle linked to the scandal. For the moment
column2: this is a civil
column3: not a criminal case
column4: which means no individuals will be prosecuted.

column1: The US is taking an interest. The justice department
column2: the treasury department and the Securities and Exchange Commission
column3: which regulates US stock markets
column4: are reportedly involved.

column1: Denmark’s regulator
column2: the Financial Supervisory Authority
column3: has reopened an investigation that it had closed in May. Its first inquiry resulted in a reprimand
column4: but no fine. Now the authority will look at whether management should face legal action. Its head
column5: Jesper Berg
column6: told the Financial Times: “It’s easy to understand that there’s a lot of public uproar. It’s a continuation of the financial crisis. There’s this sense of unmet consequences for the financial sector.”

column1: Before being rewarded with the top job
column2: Borgen had been responsible for Estonia as Danske’s head of international operations from 2009-12. The chief executive
column3: in his resignation statement
column4: said the report concluded he had “lived up” to his legal obligations. There are concerns
column5: however
column6: that the person at the helm during a catastrophic failure of the bank’s internal controls is not leaving immediately. Borgen is being retained until a replacement is found and
column8: he is entitled to collect a year’s pay.

column1: Many questions remain unanswered. Even as the number of law enforcement agencies trying to tackle the Danske problem grows
column2: doubts are mounting about their ability to bring prosecutions. Money laundering is a transnational crime. The Danske scandal involves 32 currencies
column3: companies from Cyprus
column4: the British Virgin Islands and the Seychelles. Customers of the Estonian branch have been traced to Russia
column5: Azerbaijan and Ukraine.

column1: One scheme run through the branch reportedly involved Azerbaijan’s ruling elite
column2: and a $2.9bn (£2.2bn) fund used to pay European politicians and lobbyists.

column1: “Money laundering is a globalised industry and if you operate on a domestic basis you might as well not bother
column2: ” said Tom Keatinge
column3: the director of the centre for financial crime and security studies at the Royal United Services Institute. A former investment banker
column4: Keatinge worked at JP Morgan for 20 years before turning his attention to combating fraud. “The borders are immaterial to you when you are structuring these transactions
column5: whereas the borders are not immaterial for the cops who are trying to chase you.”

column1: Last week
column2: the European commission put forward proposals to create the EU’s first genuine cross-border anti-money laundering force. The European Banking Authority will see its relevant investigations team increased from two people to 10
column3: and the agency is to be handed the power to intervene where it believes national regulators are failing. But its mandate is limited to taking action against banks – it cannot prosecute their criminal customers.

column1: Neither this week’s 87-page report
column2: produced for Danske by an independent law firm
column3: Bruun and Hjejle
column4: nor a 19-page memorandum by the Danish FSA outlining Danske’s failings in May
column5: have confirmed the names of any of the bank’s suspicious clients. Five years after staff in Estonia began raising the alarm
column6: the only revelations in this area have come from investigative reporters.

column1: The Bruun and Hjejle report makes a glancing reference to the most eye-catching name: the Putin family. It confirms that in December 2013
column2: a whistleblower’s account was sent to a member of Danske’s executive board. The whistleblower named a UK registered company with an account at Danske whose beneficial owners were suspected to include “the Putin family and the FSB”.

column1: Bruun and Hjejle referenced reporting by the Danish newspaper Berlingske
column2: which last year named Igor Putin
column3: a businessman and cousin of the Russian president
column4: and a number of his associates
column5: as the individuals suspected by Danske staff of having transacted money through its Estonian accounts. Putin did not respond to a request for comment from Berlingske.

column1: The transactions centred on a UK-registered company called Lantana Trade LLP. England’s limited liability partnerships are notoriously popular for money laundering
column2: because the information they are obliged to disclose is minimal. Companies House lists 50
column3: 000 active LLPs.

column1: Lantana had filed accounts claiming to be dormant
column2: according to the Danish FSA report from May. But Danske staff noticed in the summer of 2012 that it had an extensive history of transactions and a credit balance of nearly $1m. The alarm was raised with managers
column3: but instead of closing the account
column4: they allowed Lantana to remain a client until September 2013.

column1: The NCA will not name the company it is investigating. The only detail given is that it is an LLP. In a statement
column2: the agency did acknowledge the role often played by English companies in illegal schemes. “The threat posed by the use of UK company structures as a route for money laundering is widely recognised and the NCA is working with partners across government to restrict the ability of criminals to use them in this way.”

column1: The government says it is considering how to bolster the ability of the Companies House team to check the information provided by entities on its register. But for Keatinge
column2: information gathering is not enough. “We know that supervision doesn’t get the bad guys
column3: ” he said. “It’s investigation that gets the bad guys.”"	"[{'query': {'id': '1605050834208-421aab2f07a3411a'

column110: working closely with US authorities
column111: has cracked down on one of Honduras’ largest drug transport organizations
column112: the Cachiros
column113:
seizing properties and businesses and in the process painting a picture of a group whose reach may extend to Honduras’ political and possibly its financial elite.

\n

Honduras police and military have identified 61 properties
column114: 4 commercial establishments
column115: and 24 vehicles in two provinces for seizure
column116: as well as 64 dollar and lempira bank accounts to be frozen at the US Treasury Department’s behest
column117:
La Prensa reported.

\n

The US Treasury estimated the value of the assets at $500 million
column118:
the newspaper said.

\n

In a statement
column119: the Treasury said the Cachiros is headed by Javier and Leonel Rivera Maradiaga
column120: and its members include their father
column121: Santos Isidro Rivera Cardona
column122: mother
column123: Esperanza Caridad Maradiaga Lopez
column124: sister
column125: Maira Lizeth Rivera Maradiaga
column126: and brother
column127:
Santos Isidro Rivera Maradiaga. They do not face charges in Honduras and no formal indictment has been released in the United States.

\n

As opposed to its July 1 statement
column128: in which it named the group as “specially designated narcotics traffickers” without providing details
column129: the Treasury this time identified several companies the group controls
column130: among them a mining operation
column131: a cattle ranch
column132:
an African Palm oil processor and a zoo.

\n

An anonymous Treasury source told El Heraldo\xa0that there were “dozens” of companies and proxies laundering money for the organization.

\n

The money comes from the group’s lucrative drug trafficking business
column133:
which the Treasury detailed in its statement.

\n

“Los Cachiros coordinates the movement of drugs to and from Honduras for Colombian and Mexican drug trafficking organizations
column134: including the Sinaloa Cartel
column135: ” the Treasury said. “Los Cachiros employs land
column136: air
column137: and sea conveyances in its movement of drugs
column138: and its activities have been linked to seizures of cocaine in Central America. It is reported that Los Cachiros controls 90 percent of the clandestine airstrips in Honduras
column139:
and it uses these airstrips to facilitate the entry of drugs into Honduras and Guatemala.”

\n

InSight Crime Analysis

\n

If you look at the organizational chart provided by the Treasury (see below
column140: or for complete version see attachment)
column141: you might mistake this group for a small
column142:
rural band of gangsters. But this organization has deep contacts in the country’s elite that keep their money safe and the judicial authorities at bay. It also has a distribution network that stretches into three countries.

\n

At least part of their reach came to light in a cable released by Wikileaks\xa0in which outgoing Ambassador Charles Ford spoke candidly about then President Manuel Zelaya. In the cable
column143:
Ford talks of ways in which criminal groups “have pressured [Zelaya] to name one of their own” to a high level post in the Security Ministry.

\n

One of those groups was presumably the Cachiros
column144: who
column145: when their candidate was not selected
column146: took it personally. Senator Juan Ramon Salgado Cuevas was assassinated shortly thereafter
column147:
and Honduran intelligence told InSight Crime it was because Salgado had failed to secure the Cachiros’ candidate for the ministry job.

\n

The Treasury also does not mention the family’s possible link to the Tocoa soccer club
column148: Real Sociedad Municipal
column149: whose players wear on their chests the logo of Joya Grande
column150: the zoo in question
column151:
and whose ownership has been tied to the Cachiros.
The club counts Banco Continental — a company managed by one of the country’s wealthiest families — as one of its other sponsors.

\n

The support has worked. The club has moved to the first division where it is considered one of the best teams.\xa0

\n

The Treasury does make reference to the distribution chain
column152: noting that Nicaraguan authorities arrested Nicaraguan national and alleged Cachiros associate Bismarck Antonio Lira Jiron last August. He remains in custody in Nicaragua
column153:
facing charges of drug trafficking with the Cachiros to the north and the Norte del Valle Cartel in Colombia to the south.

\n

However
column154: the Cachiros main contacts are along the Guatemala – Honduras border where they can pass cocaine to their Guatemalan and Mexican counterparts
column155: collecting about $2
column156: 000 per kilo. If it is true that they control 90 percent of the air traffic coming through Honduras
column157: then that would make some healthy profits. By InSight Crime’s estimates
column158: the family grosses up to $4 million per month from its trafficking operations
column159:
which are concentrated in the Colon province.

\n

The Cachiros are the second large organization from Honduras that the US Treasury has outed in recent months. The other is led by Jose Miguel “Chepe” Handal Perez
column160: a politician and businessman operating from San Pedro Sula
column161:
who is at large after the US added him to the same list the Cachiros made in July.

\n

As they did with Handal
column162:
Honduran authorities have declared that battle is being waged. The head of the Senate’s banking committee called on banks to stop doing business with money launderers; a frontrunner in November’s presidential elections said all candidates should “abstain from using dirty money.”

\n

But sincerity is in short supply in Honduras. Santos Isidro Rivera was arrested briefly earlier this year on weapons charges but released. Leonel was arrested in 2011
column163:
but also released.\xa0

\n

The Honduran state has largely collapsed
column164: leaving a rich stew of corruption and drug trafficking
column165: which is now boiling over. Witness the fact that the Cachiros have a road construction business
column166:
the perfect way to feed corrupt politicians and launder illicit proceeds at the same time.

\n

Drug traffickers still appear to fear the United States
column167: especially the prospect of extradition
column168: which the Honduras government recently\xa0green-lighted. However
column169: only one person
column170: who was not a Honduran
column171: has been extradited since
column172: and while the United States is pressuring the Honduran government to start capturing and extraditing local suspects
column173: the subject appears to be too sensitive
column174:
especially with presidential elections coming.

\n

To be sure
column175: the United States
column176: despite providing millions in support for the security and judicial authorities in Honduras
column177: seems to have run out of ways to pressure the Honduran state to reform its own institutions and to take action on its own. And while efforts such as the move to tackle the Cachiros\xa0are an important first step
column178: they came at the behest of a powerful outsider
column179: not a reform-minded
column180:
courageous Honduran seeking to change the direction of this nation.

column189:
'articleBodyHtml': '

WASHINGTON – The U.S. Department of the Treasury today designated six individuals and four entities linked to the Brothers’ Circle
column190: a Eurasian crime syndicate
column191: pursuant to Executive Order\n(E.O.) 13581
column192: which targets significant transnational criminal organizations\n(TCOs).\xa0 Today’s actions are focused on the criminal networks of two key\nmembers of the Brothers Circle
column193: Vladislav Leontyev and Gafur Rakhimov
column194: both of whom were designated by the Treasury Department for acting on behalf of the Brothers’ Circle in February 2012.\xa0 Today’s designations include individuals and businesses in Europe
column195: Asia
column196:
and the Middle East working on behalf of Leontyev and Rakhimov and support Treasury’s efforts to disrupt the illicit financial networks that provide revenue and support for their global criminal activities.

“The key to targeting transnational criminal organizations
column197: \nsuch as the Brothers’ Circle
column198: is exposing the network behind the group’s leaders
column199:
which we have done today.\xa0 We remain determined to continue our systematic
effort to disrupt these networks in order to protect the U.S. financial system
from abuse by these criminals
column200:
” said Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence David S. Cohen.

The Brothers’ Circle is one of five TCOs sanctioned under E.O. 13581
column201: along with the Camorra
column202: the Yakuza
column203: Los Zetas
column204:
and MS-13.\xa0 Today’s action brings to 28 the total number of individuals and entities designated by the Treasury Department for acting for or on behalf of the Brothers’ Circle.

The Brothers’ Circle is a criminal group composed of leaders and senior members of several Eurasian criminal groups that are largely based in the countries of the former Soviet Union
column205: but which also operate in Europe
column207: Africa
column208: and Latin America. The Brothers’ Circle serves as a\ncoordinating body for several criminal networks
column209: mediates disputes between\nindividual criminal networks
column210:
and directs member criminal activity globally.

Today’s action generally prohibits U.S. persons from conducting financial or commercial transactions with these entities and individuals
column211:
and freezes any assets they may have under U.S. jurisdiction.

Targets Linked to Vladislav Leontyev

Vladislav Leontyev was designated by the Treasury Department under E.O. 13581 on February 23
column213: for acting for or on behalf of the\nBrothers’ Circle.\xa0 Vladislav Leontyev is a key member of the Brothers’\nCircle and has been involved in various criminal activities
column214:
including
narcotics trafficking.\xa0 He was also involved in a shooting between
regional factions within Russian organized criminal networks over an attempt to
seize control of a local precious metals enterprise.\xa0 The following
individuals were designated today
column215: along with entities they own or control
column216:
because they act for or on behalf of Vladislav Leontyev:

Vadim Lyalin serves as a conduit for passing messages on behalf of Vladislav Leontyev;

Grigory Lepsveridze couriers money on behalf of Vladislav Leontyev;

Igor Shlykov has worked to get identification documents and to develop business opportunities in Africa on Vladislav Leontyev’s behalf.\xa0 Igor Shlykov also owns or controls M S Group Invest OOO and Meridian Jet Management GmbH based in Russia and Austria respectively.\xa0 He is the director-general of M S Group Invest OOO and owns 60 percent of Meridian Jet Management GmbH;

Gurgen House FZCO is owned or controlled by Lazar Shaybazian who was designated in February 2012
column217: for acting for or on behalf of Vladislav\nLeontyev.\xa0 Gurgen House FZCO has offices in the U.A.E.
column219:
and Russia. Lazar Shaybazian uses Gurgen House FZCO to move money.

Targets Linked to Gafur Rakhimov

In February 2012
column220:
Gafur Rakhimov was designated by the Treasury Department pursuant to E.O. 13581 for acting on behalf of the Brothers’ Circle.\xa0 Gafur Rakhimov is a key member of the Brothers’ Circle and one of the leaders of Uzbek organized crime with a specialty in the organized production of drugs in Central Asia.\xa0 He has operated major international drug syndicates involving the trafficking of heroin.\xa0 Sergey Moskalenko and Yakov Rybalskiy were designated today by the Treasury Department because they act for or on behalf of Gafur Rakhimov.

Artur Badalyan

Artur Badalyan and his company Fasten Tourism LLC were designed today pursuant to E.O. 13581 because they are used by key members of the Brothers’ Circle to courier money and make travel arrangements.\xa0 Artur Badalyan is the owner and CEO of Fasten Tourism LLC.

For a chart detailing Treasury actions against the Brothers’ Circle click here.

column1: 9	Carel	Frans Timmermans	Individual	https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/IP_17_1732	"The Juncker Commission has made the fight against tax avoidance
column2: money laundering and terrorism financing one of its priorities.

column1: Today
column2: the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive enters into force. It strengthens the existing rules and will make the fight against money laundering and terrorism financing more effective. It also improves transparency to prevent tax avoidance. This entry into force comes as discussions with the European Parliament and the Council on extra measures further reinforcing the Directive are already at an advanced stage.

column1: Today the Commission also publishes a report which will support Member State authorities in better addressing money laundering risks in practice. As required by the new directive
column2: the Commission assessed the money laundering and terrorist financing risks of different sectors and financial products. The report published today identifies the areas most at risk and the most widespread techniques used by criminals to launder illicit funds.

column1: Frans Timmermans
column2: First Vice-President said: ""Laundered money is oxygen to crime
column3: terrorism and tax-avoidance. We need to cut off its supply as best we can. Today's stronger rules are a big step forward but we now need quick agreement on the further improvements the Commission proposed last July.""

column1: Věra Jourová
column2: Commissioner for Justice
column3: Consumers and Gender Equality said: “Terrorists and criminals still find ways to finance their activities and to launder illicit gains back into the economy. The new rules as of today are crucial to closing further loopholes. I urge all Member States to put them in place without delay: lower standards in one country will weaken the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing across the EU. I also call for quick agreement on the further revisions proposed by the Commission following the ""Panama Papers"" to increase transparency of beneficial ownership.""

column1: Strengthening the existing rules
The Fourth Anti-Money Laundering  reinforces the existing rules by introducing the following changes:
reinforcing the risk assessment obligation for banks
column2: lawyers
column3: and accountants;

column1: setting clear transparency requirements about beneficial ownership for companies. This information will be stored in a central register
column2: such as commercial registers
column3: and will be available to national authorities and obliged entities

column1: facilitating cooperation and exchange of information between Financial Intelligence Units from different Member States to identify and follow suspicious transfers of money to prevent and detect crime or terrorist activities;
establishing a coherent policy towards non-EU countries that have deficient anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing rules;
reinforcing the sanctioning powers of competent authorities.
In July 2016
column2: the Commission adopted a proposal to further reinforce these EU rules on anti-money laundering to counter terrorist financing and increase transparency about who really owns companies and trusts. The Commission calls on the European Parliament and the Council to finalise this legislative work as soon as possible
column3: so the new rules can enter into force quickly. Building on the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive
column4: these new rules will create a robust EU anti-money laundering framework.

column1: Improving the risk assessment across the internal market
The Supranational Risk Assessment Reportis a tool to help Member States identify
column2: analyse and address money laundering and terrorist financing risks. It analyses the risks in the financial and non-financial sector and looks also into newly emerging risks such as virtual currencies or crowdfunding platforms. The report includes:

column1: an extensive mapping of risks per relevant area and a list of the means more frequently used by criminals to launder money.
recommendations to Member States how to address identified risks appropriately
column2: for example by putting more emphasis on risk analysis or supervisory actions on specific activities.

column1: Finally the Commission also commits to examining options to enhance the operation and cross-border cooperation of Financial Intelligence Units.
Next steps
On the 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive
The Member States should have notified the transposition of the 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive by today
column2: 26 June 2017. The European Commission will now check the state of the transposition and follow up swiftly with Member States in case they have not taken the necessary measures yet.

column1: On the Supranational Risk Assessment Report
The Commission will carry out the necessary actions outlined in the report
column2: including examining options to enhance the operation and cross-border cooperation of Financial Intelligence Units through specific EU rules. It will also engage with Member States to monitor the implementation of the recommendations.

column1: The Commission will continue reviewing the evolution of Anti-Money Laundry/Counter Financing Terrorism risks and will issue a new assessment of those risks at the latest by June 2019 and every two years thereafter.
Background
The new anti-money laundering framework consists of two legal instruments (IP/15/5001): ‘The Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive' and ‘the Fund Transfers Regulation'
column2: both adopted on 20 May 2015.

column1: In July 2016
column2: the Commission presented a proposal to better counter the financing of terrorism and to ensure increased transparency of financial transactions following the so-called ""Panama Papers"" revelations (IP/16/2380). These amendments aim at ensuring a high level of safeguards for financial flows from high-risk third countries
column3: enhancing the access of Financial Intelligence Units to information
column4: including centralised bank account registers
column5: and tackling terrorist financing risks linked to virtual currencies and pre-paid cards. The proposal is currently in negotiations in the Council and the European Parliament and is expected to be adopted in the course of 2017."	[{'error': 'Proxy error: ssl_tunnel_error'

Payments firm Afterpay can move on with its life as it has been cleared by the Australian regulator over compliance issues with anti-money laundering (AML) rules.

It was back in June 2019 when Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) ordered the appointment of an external auditor to the Tencent-backed firm to examine its compliance with the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing (CTF) Act 2006.

AUSTRAC had identified concerns with the buy now
column32:
pay later (BNPL) firm – such as identification and verification of customers; and suspicious matter reporting obligations.

  • Afterpay to purchase Pagantis for €50m in European payments push

In November last year an independent audit found that the issues arose because Afterpay breached AML laws due to incorrect legal advice about how to comply.

Today (14 October) the regulator says in response to the findings and recommendations identified in the external audit report
column33: Afterpay has “uplifted” its AML/CTF compliance framework and financial crime function
column34:
and completed all remediation necessary to ensure compliance.

AUSTRAC has “decided not to undertake further regulatory action”.

But it will continue to work with the Melbourne-based company to ensure its obligations
column35:
etc.

This good news for Afterpay follows the positive development in August when it entered into an agreement with NBQ to acquire Pagantis and PMT Technology for €50 million. That gave it a real boost for its European fintech ambitions.

Prior to that

column37: famous for its communications platforms Weixin
column38: WeChat and QQ
column39:
got a 5% stake.

Afterpay launched in 2015 and like Klarna – another healthy BNPL firm – is doing well. Last month the Australian paytech had a market capitalisation on the ASX of around AU$22 billion ($16 billion).

column1: 149	Sebastien			https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/markets/the-world-is-losing-the-money-laundering-fight/ar-BB19gttL	"(Bloomberg Opinion) -- We’ve just had the closest look yet at the global battle against money laundering
column2: and it’s deeply troubling: Banks and their regulators are nowhere near restraining the flow of trillions of dollars of illicit funds.

column1: Both the finance industry and the authorities are to blame. Without an urgent
column2: concerted political effort
column3: criminals — from drug dealers and terrorists to human traffickers — will keep the upper hand.

column1: In a year-long investigation by BuzzFeed and the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists
column2: reporters pored over about 2
column3: 100 suspicious activity reports
column4: or SARs
column5: which lenders file to the U.S. Treasury’s Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) when they spot potential money laundering and other bad behavior.

column1: While the number of SARs reviewed by the journalists dwarfs any previous access to these confidential documents
column2: they’re still just a tiny fraction — 0.02% — of the 12 million or so SARs that were probably filed during the period in question
column3: mostly 2011 through 2017. Also
column4: the sample isn’t representative of overall banking activity. Some records stem from the U.S. congressional investigation into interference with the 2016 presidential election. Almost half of the SARs came from Deutsche Bank AG.

column1: Still
column2: the sums and the patterns of failings are staggering. This small number of reports alone flagged up $2 trillion of fund flows
column3: $1.3 trillion from Deutsche Bank
column4: that may have stemmed from criminal activity. And the FinCEN Files are just the tip of the iceberg
column5: as Transparency International put it. (The banks’ responses to BuzzFeed are here.)

column1: The U.K.
column2: home to more than 600 companies flagged in the reports
column3: appears to be the biggest hub for dodgy money flows
column4: with the U.S. second. Britain clearly hasn’t done enough to tighten laws against money launderers. A huge web of enablers
column5: from lawyers to accountants and bankers
column6: helps oil the wheels of illicit finance through London.

column1: Banks
column2: for their part
column3: are too slow if not outright negligent in submitting SARs. More than a fifth of the documents included in the submissions related to subjects whose addresses weren’t known to the banks
column4: including companies with whom the lenders were already banking.

column1: SARs
column2: which should be filed within 60 days of detecting potential criminal activity
column3: were sometimes submitted years later. According to the BuzzFeed/ICIJ report
column4: that was allegedly the case with JPMorgan Chase & Co.
column5: which processed payments for Paul Manafort
column6: President Donald Trump’s former campaign manager
column7: after he resigned from the 2016 campaign amid money-laundering allegations. HSBC Holdings Plc kept moving money for an investment fund that was already under investigation over allegations it was a Ponzi scheme

column1: Alarmingly
column2: banks often just rely on internet searches to find out who their clients are and only file suspicious reports after news breaks or formal investigations are launched. In the bundle of SARs reviewed by the reporters
column3: the median filing time since the suspicious activity began was 166 days. Imagine how far those funds would have gone in half a year.

column1: The reviewed SARs pertain to a period when many banks were already being investigated and punished for failing to adhere to money-laundering regulation. But the billions of dollars in fines levied against them haven’t changed behavior much.

Having a bigger legal stick with which to whack errant bankers and other enablers would help. So too would a rethink of how money laundering is tackled by policy makers. Police forces and national regulators don’t only struggle to cooperate across borders; even within some crime agencies
column2: various units don’t always share information.

column1: Tom Kirchmaier
column2: a policing and crime researcher at the London School of Economics
column3: suggests a three-step solution. For starters
column4: the SARs filings must be standardized. Far too much information is submitted in narratives that are impossible to scrutinize. FinCEN employs about 270 employees
column5: receiving up to 2 million SARs every year. “We’re still stuck in the 19th century
column6: ” Switzerland’s former top money-laundering cop Daniel Thelesklaf says of his nation’s paper-based efforts.

column1: Second
column2: Kirchmaier calls for far more sharing of data between regulators and enforcers. In Europe
column3: more than 50 authorities supervise money laundering and terror financing. The European Commission will propose an EU-level supervisor next year. That’s long overdue.

column1: Lastly
column2: Kirchmaier says humans need to be removed from the process as far as possible. Crime agencies should be able to automate the screening of SARs and report back to banks
column3: providing them with an assessment of the risk associated with a particular client
column4: for example. And lenders ought to be able to stop transactions to flagged entities without so much human intervention.

column1: A radical improvement in the fight against money laundering may not be possible overnight
column2: but — as I’ve written before — the system isn’t working. As the speed of payments accelerates and virtual currencies proliferate
column3: criminals will find new ways to move money. Banks and their supervisors collectively need to do much
column4: much better.

column346: to be Secretary of Commerce. Incredibly - perhaps I should write

column351:
\xa0should be going viral. Palast wrote:

\n
Pritzker’s net worth is listed in Forbes as $1.8 billion
column352: which is \xa0one hell of a heavy magic wand in the world of politics. Her wand would \xa0have been heavier
column355: the federal government fined her and her family $460 million for the predatory
column357: racist tactics and practices of Superior
column358:
the bank-and-loan-shark operation she ran on the South Side of Chicago.\n

Superior was the first of the deregulated go-go banks to go bust – at \xa0the time
column359:
the costliest failure ever. US taxpayers lost nearly half a billion dollars. Superior’s depositors lost millions and poor folk in Sen. Obama’s South Side district lost their homes.

\n\nThere were also \xa0a couple diaries on DailyKos
column360: including by front pager Laura Clawson

column362: which has compiled what may be the worst records of labor abuses in the hotel industry. Incredibly
column367: and unaware liberals and progressives can be

""She\'s not the monster you think she is.""\n

Even President Obama rushed to show that he was likewise uninformed
column372: though at this point I\'m not about to attach the labels ""liberal"" or ""progressive"" to him. \xa0""She\'s built companies from the ground up
column373:
Obama said. ""She knows from experience that no government program alone can take the place of a great entrepreneur.""

\n

There once were
column376: veterans of the labor strife of the 1920s and 1930s
column377: you could sit down with in a neighborhood tavern
column378: and during the course of an evening
column379: well lubricated by a few pitchers of beer
column380: tell you more than you really wanted to know about who was actually running your town. How the police chief\'s kids got really good paying jobs because the chief would not make too many inquiries about (in other words
column383: and unaware) the prostitution on the West Side; or the numbers racket along the riverfront; or the freight pilferage at the airport. How the mayor\'s wife was able to drive around in a brand new Cadillac because a certain tract of land had been quietly rezoned
column384: to the advantage a mayoral crony. Such petty corruption used to be the stock in trade of good local investigative reporters at big metropolitan newspapers
column385: back in a nearly forgotten era when FCC rules made it nearly impossible for one or two corporate behemoths to own every major newspaper
column387:
and television station in one city.

column388: and that I burned out and became depressed watching Wall Street have its way in the early 1990s in what was called
column390: ""off balance sheet liabilities"" (what we today call ""financial derivatives"" - the stuff
column393: and left a dismaying amount of the world\'s economy in ashes). Well

column398: frightful secrets hidden away in my memory; stuff I usually don\'t mention

because it makes a lot of people very uncomfortable. \xa0

\n

In a word
column400: the mob. Organized crime. The syndicate. In Chicago
column401: it was called the Outfit. But every major city had its own crime family
column403: part of what I researched and wrote about in that depressing period of nearly a quarter century ago was how the billions of dollars
column405: hundreds of billions of dollars that were fueling what was politely called mergers and acquisitions
column406: most especially including leveraged buy outs
column410: organized crime. That included hundreds of billions of dollars that the Wall Street banks laundered from illegal narcotics trafficking
column411:
including heroin and cocaine. \xa0The beginnings of financial derivatives were closely tied to the mob going legit.

\n

So
column412: the Reagan regime of deregulation was really a double whammy. It basically decriminalized the worst behavior of banks and corporations
column413: at the very time that some of the most immoral
column416: people in America were buying legitimacy for themselves and their heirs by seizing control
column417: through brazen manipulation of debt and stock markets
column418:
of America\'s industrial companies.

\n

The story of the hour is Penny Pritzker becoming Secretary of Commerce. So
column420:
you\'re going to learn about the Pritizker family and its fortune. I suspect that it\'s probably more than you want to know.

\n

The origins of the Pritzker family fortune was her grandfather\'s mob connections when he was a tax attorney for a lot of people in ""The Outfit
column423: and continuing through the 1980s. This connection to organized crime was reportedly what financed the creation of Hyatt Hotels by Penny\'s father. There was no crime involved
column424: but the financial backing came from organized crime
column425: plain and simple. \xa0The details are in Gus Russo\'s 2006 tome Supermob: How Sidney Korshak and His Criminal Associates Became America\'s Hidden Power Brokers. Russo\'s book is crucial reading for anyone trying to understand why America\'s ruling elites are
column427:
so bad.

\n

It\'s not really a matter of incompetence or ineptitude. Rather
column428: it is a \xa0case study in how the republican (small ""r""
column429: not capital ""R"" as in the Republican Party
column430: or GOP - greedy old pricks) ideals of public virtue
column433: are forgotten and eventually undermined by allowing a criminal class to become legitimate and amass political and economic influence. The story of the Pritzker family is an all-American story
column434: of how a family with ties to organized crime amasses a great fortune while striving relentlessly for legitimacy
column435:
and arrives at the pinnacle of economic and political power in America. Chris Hedges is not exaggerating when he states that ""the criminal class in this country has seized power.""

\n

This ascent to America\'s summits is an oft-trod trek
column436: pioneered by Boston and Newport maritime merchants who parlayed opium and millions of ruined lives in China into wealth
column438: and power in the 1800s. Many of the mercantile banks established along the way are \xa0still with us
column439:
brightened and prettified by numerous changes in corporate branding. The one constant is the ruthless concentration on private gain. The extent to which that concentration on private gain is tempered and ameliorated by fleeting notions of public service provides the cracks and crevices in which the ebb and flow of history eddy and swirl. \xa0

\n

Now
column440: you can point to the Kennedy family as an example of ill-begotten gains leading to some very good minded public service. But <a href=""http://org2.salsalabs.com/dia/track.jsp?v=2&c=qxdTh40W95P%2BlywDB2hYK33wNl4%2FZnQ3"">Penny Pritzker\'s roles at Hyatt and Superior Bank are
column443: and cast doubt on the idea that she may be anywhere near as mindful of the general welfare as John
column445: and Edward Kennedy were. Instead of public service
column446: the tradition in the Pritzker family seems focused on economic exploitation of others
column447: skirting the law as much as possible
column448:
and shady dealings. There is a strong tradition in the Pritzker family of outright money laundering and offshore tax evasion.
