Before Superior Bank
column450: a loan company in Chicago that one source told Russo ""is believed to be the secret to the origins of the family\'s involvement with criminals."" The president of Frontier Finance was Frank Buccieri. And Buccieri\'s brother was the greatly feared ""collector"" for the Outfit
column452:
who Life magazine in May 1969 termed ""leader of [Sam] Giancana\'s assassination squads."" The Wikipedia entry on Fiori Buccieri is chilling:

\n
During \xa0the bootleg wars of Prohibition
column453: Buccieri was reportedly involved in at least 10 gangland slayings. In the 1960s
column454: following Giancana\'s rise to the day-to-day ""boss"" position in the Outfit
column455: Buccieri served as a top enforcer and personal hitman. He was also involved in labor racketeering \xa0bombing
column456:
arson and loan sharking.\n

As a loan shark
column457: Buccieri would send his men to stake out employment offices. These thugs would pass out business cards to the unemployed that listed Buccieri as a
column458: ""loan officer."" The mob generally viewed unemployed workers as poor loan prospects; however
column459: Buccieri was so effective at intimidating his ""juice
column461: victims that they would steal or rob to pay him off. Buccieri would often warn friends of a ""juice"" victim not to ride around with him
column462: ""because he is going to get hit."" When the victim heard this warning
column463:
he would quickly pay up.

\n\nIt is not clear whether Fiore Buccieri\'s ""sales pitches"" at employment offices fed ""clients"" to his brother\'s (and Pritzker\'s) Frontier Finance
column464: but that is a reasonable assumption. Buccieri used a warehouse where he would hang his victims on a meathook (maybe Hollywood got this gruseome idea from its mob connections?)
column465: the most infamous such murder was that of loanshark William ""Action"" Jackson
column466: in 1961. After being arrested while unloading a truck of stolen radios then released
column467: rumor spread within the Outfit that Jackson had become an FBI informant. \xa0Buccieri and two others hung the 300-pound Jackson on a meat hook and tortured him with ice picks
column469: a blow torch and an electric cattle prod for nearly three days
column470:
until Jackson finally died. Federal authorities later obtained details of Jackson\'s murder from conversations overheard between Buccieri and one of the other murderers. \xa0\n

But
column472: so far all we have is guilt by association. Uh
column473: yeah. Get over it. In fact
column474: learn to use it. You want a criminal indictment or conviction? Ain\'t going to happen. Not for the most successful criminals. As Russo quotes John P. Barnes
column475: Judge of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois from the 1930s top 1950s: “The Syndicate could not operate without the approval of the [State\'s Attorney\'s] office.... The relationship between the State\'s Attorney\'s office
column478: was such that during the entire period that Courtney was in office [1932-44]
column479:
no Syndicate man was ever convicted of a major crime in Cook County.""

\n

A specialty developed and refined by the Chicago Outfit was labor racketeering. Al Capone\'s very own lawyer
column480: Abe Teitelbaum got the bar rolling when he was ""hired\' as the attorney for the Chicago Bar and Restaurant Association in 1932. As the U.S. Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in Labor and Management (also known as the McClellan Committee) stated in its final report in 1950
column483:
functioned ""principally to to defeat and destroy legitimate unionization and has callously and calculatedly used men with underworld connections to make collusive arrangements with dishonest union officials.""

\n

Teitelbaum\'s labor racketeering became of forte of Sidney Korshak
column484:
who would become a key Pritzker associate. Russo writes that

\n
In the case of unions not directly under the mob\'s control
column485: it was often just a simple matter of paying off the union bosses to persuade them to accept a substandard deal
column486: a modus operandi adopted by Sid Korshak. ""He made cash payoffs to business agents - five thousand dollars here
column489: a Los Angeles attorney who negotiated with Korshak years later. ""I know that. That\'s the way it was--to keep labor peace
column490: you\'d find a corrupt business agent and pay him off."" Of course
column492: the racketeer stabbed both the workers and their employers in the back. Ironically
column493: this was the very abuse suffered by Korshak\'s grandparents in Kiev. The ever-vigiulent Korshak gadfly
column495: succinctly described [in Readers Digest in 1957] how the treachery worked: ""The deal may be to bring a ""friendly"" union in
column496: or to keep a union out
column497: or to accept substandard wages.... In the deals that the go-between arranges
column498: the union\'s function is perverted. Instead of serving as an instrument to win better wages and working conditions
column499: it becomes a tool for keeping the worker in line. Thus it performs the same function as the unions do in Communist Russia.""\nWhat do you think? Would it be impolite to ask Penny Pritizker
column501:
about her grandfather\'s relations to organized crime? Is it impolite to ask her if her ideas about suppressing workers wages are in any way informed or influenced by the role of her grandfather\'s associates in smashing and corrupting unions? It does seem to be a tradition in her family.\n

Is it impolite to ask about the similarities in the business models of \xa0Frontier Finance in the 1950s and Superior Bank in the 1990s? And is Penny Pritzker now willing
column503: to condemn the type of banking practices that seem to be another family tradition among the Pritzkers? \xa0Back in February 2008
column506:
\n
Though Superior Bank collapsed years before the current sub-prime turmoil that is rocking the world’s financial markets – and pushing those millions of homeowners toward foreclosure – some banking experts say the Pritzkers and Superior hold a special place \xa0in the history of the sub-prime fiasco.\n

“The [sub-prime] financial engineering that created the Wall Street meltdown was developed by the Pritzkers and Ernst and Young
column507: working with Merrill Lynch to sell bonds securitized by sub-prime mortgages
column509: a whistleblower on financial and bank fraud
column510:
told me in an interview.

\n

“The sub-prime mortgages
column513: by a nation-wide Pritzker origination system
column514: using Superior as the cash cow
column515: with many millions in FDIC insured deposits. Superior’s owners were to sub-prime lending
column516:
what Michael Milken was to junk bonds”

\n

In other words
column517: if you traced today’s sub-prime crisis back to its origins
column518:
you would come upon the
\nrole of the Pritzkers and Superior Bank of Chicago.... When it collapsed in 2001
column519:
Superior Bank represented the largest failure of a U.S.-insured depository institution for a decade.

\n

“The failure of Superior Bank was directly attributable to the Bank’s Board of Directors and executives ignoring sound risk management principles
column520: ” said FDIC Inspector General Gaston Gianni Jr. in a Feb. 7
column522:
report.

\n

Banking whistleblower Anderson noted that “Superior failed at a time of historically low interest rates
column525: and a growing housing market.… There was no reason for it to fail unless you consider gross negligence
column527:
and a conspiracy to deceive the regulators who were clearly asleep and were negligent themselves in their duties of protecting the class of underinsured depositors.”

\n\nA few voices the past few weeks have raised the issue of Hyatt Hotels and Superior Bank
column530: raised an even more troubling chapter of Pritzker history: \xa0the family\'s connection to Castle Bank of the Bahamas. According to \xa0Russo (pages 439 ff.) Castle Bank was the granddaddy of offshore money laundering and tax evasion. Castle Bank was set up in 1964 by former senior Office of Strategic Services officer Paul Helliwell
column531: who had become an important cutout for hiding CIA funds; Morris Kleinman of the Cleveland organized crime family headed by Moe Dalitz; Burton Kanter
column532: a tax attorney for the Pritzkers
column533: and a board member of Hyatt; and Stanford Clinton
column534: a partner in grandpa Pritzker\'s law firm
column535: and a trustee of the <a href=""http://www.laborers.org/Commission_IBT.html"">Teamsters Pension Fund
column536: which was an important center of mob finances in the 1950s through 1960s. (Much of the financing for organized crime\'s invasion of Las Vegas came from the Teamsters Pension Fund
column537: usually at absurdly low interest rates. Russo
column539: notes that Hyatt\'s 1972 acquisition of the Four Queens casino was financed by a loan from the Teamsters Pension Fund loan at just four percent
column541: Castle Bank pioneered the development of offshore money laundering and hiding
column542: and served not only to launder illegally obtained money for US organized crime families
column543: but to launder money for the CIA to fund various covert operations around the world
column544: particularly in South America. According to Russo
column545:
\n
....it turned out that the Pritzkers were the largest depositors in one of the most notorious offshore tax havens ever devised
column546: The Castle Bank of the Bahamas
column547: which was nothing less than an intersection of the Supermob
column551: and the covert branch of the CIA--all of whom had good reason to hide their money from Uncle Sam. Bahamian and Cayman Islands banks have long been valued by those wishing to hide their money because those nations absolutely refuse to cooperate with U.S. law enforcement. Bank expert and author Penny Lernoux wrote of the main advantage of the Caribbean banks: ""Relying on a strict code of banking secrecy that makes Swiss banks look like blabbermouths
column552: hundreds of banks have set up operations in the Caribbean."" To further guarantee its clients’ anonymity
column553: Castle had arranged for Miami National Bank
column554: which was controlled by Lansky associates
column556:
then transfer the deposit list to Castle with no names attached--only code numbers.\n

Agent Furfaro was among those frustrated by the government\'s inability to follow the money trail. ""The money was getting out of the country through Western Union
column557:
Furfaro recently said. ""But we weren\'t allowed to follow it. \xa0And the foreign banks wouldn\'t let us in. We had reports that money was also being shipped in railroad cars and containers placed on ships. There was so much money that they would just weigh it instead of count it....

\n

...Given all the Pritzker associates involved in the management of Castle
column558: it came as no surprise when Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Knut Royce determined in 1982 that the Pritzkers were in fact the bank\'s largest depositors. A September 1972 IRS statement noted
column560: a former VP and director of Castle Bank] with access to the records of Castle Trust has stated that the Pritzker family of Chicago
column562:
received their initial backing from organized crime.

\n\nBy 1977
column563: IRS investigators had made things so hot for Castle Bank that it lost its banking license in the Bahamas
column564: and moved to Panama. In April 1980
column565: the Washington Post reported that not much more came of the IRS investigations because the CIA\'s Office of General Counsel warned that further pursuit of Castle ""would harm the national security."" (A scan of the Post article was online here at the time of this writing.) Russo notes that at the time the IRS investigation was terminated
column566: the IRS Commissioner was Nixon appointee Donald Alexander
column567: who was a senior partner in the Cincinnati law firm of Dinsmore
column569: Coates and Deupree - which law firm also had accounts with Castle Bank. Alexander either ordered or accepted the termination of the investigation into Castle Bank
column570:
despite it having already recovered $52.5 million in tax penalties.\n

Frontier Finance. Castle Bank. Superior Bank. If you don\'t see a pattern yet
column571: Russo reports on page 521 that when the Pritzkers began to develop their Hyatt hotels in Saudi Arabia
column572: they partnered with the Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI)
column573: at one time the seventh largest private bank in the world. In July 1991
column574: customs and bank regulators in seven countries raided and seized the branch offices of BCCI in their countries because BCCI was involved in massive money laundering and other financial crimes worldwide. In 1986
column575: a US Customs undercover operation had infiltrated BCCI and found the bank actively solicited deposits from drug traffickers and money launderers
column576: including the Medellin Cartel. Among BCCI\'s clients were Saddam Hussein
column578: Hussain Mohammad Ershad and Samuel Doe. USMC Colonel Oliver North used multiple accounts at BCCI to fund Reagan\'s Iran-Contra operations. And
column580:
the CIA also used BCCI to finance and buy arms for the Afghan mujahideen fighting the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan. \xa0

\n

Maybe not all rich people are bad. Maybe there are some that made lots of money actually doing something useful. I personally don\'t think so. I don’t believe there are that many rich people – and I mean people in the top one percent
column581: people with a hundred million or more
column582: and most especially I mean billionaires – who got rich honestly and without hurting a lot of people on their way to the top. When I review the history of the Pritzker family
column583: and its rise to political power in the person of Penny Pritzker
column584: I think it is just the most recent example of the process the Bible describes about how a nation comes to be ruled by mean-spirited and unjust people. Then I look at the destruction of America\'s working class since 1980
column585:
and I see the warnings of the Bible about the disasters that befall such a nation being fulfilled.

\n

Penny Pritzker
column587: is a perfectly charming and very nice lady. I have no doubt she throws nice parties
column588: and donates to very worthwhile charities
column589: and is a pillar of her local community. But honestly
column590: screw Godwin’s law: the very same was said about a lot of Germans in the 1950s who were officers and guards at Nazi death camps just a few years before. Why is it so hard to comprehend that someone can be a sweet and wonderful parent and grandparent
column593: yet make a living being the most despicably ruthless corporate banditti. I mean
column594: who are the people who work at the banks that foreclosed on the homes of actively deployed servicemen and women? Or the people that are now overseeing the robo-signing the latest wave of <a href=""http://www.alternet.org/economy/vicious-new-bank-shakedown-could-seriously-ruin-your-life?akid=10451.103280.rOtZ8F&rd=1&src=newsletter841937&t=7&paging=off"">fraudulent bank actions
column595: collection of credit card debt? Maybe we don’t like to think about this; maybe we’re much more comfortable reading about the latest corporate or bankster ripoff
column596: or corruption of our political life
column598: and not actually know the people who occupy those corporate offices and cubicles day in and day out
column599: and whose job it is that results in those ripoffs
column601: and oil spills. Maybe it’s easier for us if we refuse to see them for who they are
column602: and instead maintain in our mind a cartoonish caricature of a villain
column605:
and the menacing five o’clock shadow.

\n

But
column606: I ask you to take a breath and think of Penny Pritzker. She was the head of a hotel chain that committed serial violations of labor law
column609: systematically cheated tens of thousands of employees out of wages and benefits. And before that she directed the affairs of a bank that was among the most blatant in committing financial fraud and abuse. Is Penny Pritzker a criminal? Probably not under today\'s laws in the USA. We have pretty well decriminalized criminal behavior committed under a corporate guise. And now we have a new doctrine
column610: that if there is the possibility that your enterprise is so huge and so important that its failure just might endanger the ""stability"" or the ""integrity"" of the financial system
column611:
then you will simply not be held to account. But is this the type of person you really want as your Secretary of Commerce? Is this the type of person you really want as a top adviser to the President of the United States?

\n

Perhaps it\'s a good thing to let criminal families become legitimate. They hopefully are no longer committing crimes. I can assure you
column612: this is going to be an issue many of you are going to have tpo grapple with in your own community. Just who do you think has had the money to buy real estate in inner cities and even suburbs the past five years of ""green shoots"" ""recovery""? Why
column613: it\'s been your friendly neighborhood drug dealers and money launderers! Does it make a difference who are the leaders in a community? Maybe you don\'t think so
column614: but it sure makes for popular movies: Frank Capra\'s 1946 classic
column616: in which James Stewart as bank officer George Bailey is dissuaded from suicide by an angel who shows him how debauched and evil the town becomes without his influence. Or
column617: Robert Zemeckis\' 1989 Back to the Future Part II
column618:
in which Marty and the Professor have to go back in time to stop Biff from becoming rich and totally corrupting Hill Valley. Are these just modernized fairy tales we entertain ourselves with? Or are they reflections of deeper currents of political history and social consciousness we now ignore at our peril?

\n

Should we not be concerned about the character of our leaders at the national level as well?

\n
To the promotion of interested Pursuits
column619: and the gratification of voluptuous wishes
column620: a ready sacrifice is made of the general good at the shrine of power. Then slumbers that virtuous jealousy of public men and public measures
column621: which was wont to scrutinize not only actions but motives; then nods that active zeal
column624: and with nervous arm defended the constitution. Every day new inroads are made upon public liberty
column627: grow more frequent and more dangerous in proportion as the power of resistance decreases. Thus
column628: before a nation is completely deprived of freedom
column629:
she must be fitted for slavery by her vices.\n

-- Oration Delivered at Boston
column635: Principles and Acts of the Revolution in America
column637:
1822.

\n\nWhile I am more than willing to criticize Obama about these atrocious choices for economic advisers and officials he continually makes
column638: I would prefer people focus on the problem of the pecuniary culture of our country
column639: rather than being distracted in a useless debate over whether or not Obama is a corporate shill or a Reaganite in disguise
column640: or whatever. Look at it this way: what really are the political chances that someone like Bill Black or Michael Hudson will be nominated and approved for high level economic policy positions? Or
column642: why do the greediest and most selfish people
column643: with no conception at all of the general welfare
column644: so completely dominate economic policy making in the USA? \xa0Why
column646: does the political culture spawned by the neo-liberal idea that market forces should dictate the destinies of nations rather than the people acting through the agency of their government
column648: pernicious elites? We may comfort ourselves by thinking our elites are merely incompetent
column650:
but I have reached the conclusion that such analyses is dangerous as it does not strike at the criminal essence of our elites.\n

The older I get
column651: the more bruises I suffer toiling to accumulate wisdom
column652: the more I come to appreciate what an excellent book the Bible is. Penny Pritzker
column656: consort of criminals. “By their fruits ye shall know them

I don’t need to be told. Tell yourself.

\n\n

As Vladimir Putin returns to office for a fourth term
column85:
criticism is bubbling back up over former German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder’s close relationship with the Russian president.

\n\n

A spokesman for current chancellor Angela Merkel yesterday (March 19) had to reject the suggestion that the EU sanction Schroeder for supporting Putin while the German was chancellor
column86: and then taking well-paid jobs by the Russian state after leaving office. Earlier in the day
column87:
\xa0Ukraine’s foreign minister Pavlo Klimkin had backed a call for sanctions made in a Wall Street Journal op-ed\xa0(paywall) during the weekend.

\n\n

“It is important that there are sanctions against those who promote Putin’s projects abroad
column88:
” Klimkin told the German newspaper Bild. “Schroeder is the most important lobbyist for Putin worldwide. So it should be examined how the EU can act here.”

\n\n

The two men’s relationship is so notorious that it has spawned a word used by political analysts and human rights activists in three languages: “Schroederization” in English
column89: “Schröderisierung” in German
column90: and “Schroederizatsia” (“Шрёдеризация”) in Russian. In English and Russian
column91: “it means ‘the corruption of a political elite in another country
column92: \'” said Boris Reitschuster
column93: a German former Moscow correspondent and author of\xa0Putin’s Hidden War
column94: at PutinCon
column95:
a gathering of the world’s biggest Kremlin critics on March 16.

\n\n

In German
column96: the word seems to have extra nuances. While some use it to refer to corruption
column97: one politician from Merkel’s Christian Democrats recently employed it to describe a closeness to the Kremlin. He\xa0appealed\xa0(link in German) to Schroeder’s old Social Democratic Party to not develop uncomfortably close ties to Moscow or help Kremlin propaganda
column98:
which he characterized a potential “Schroederization.”

\n\n

The phrase has been attributed to Edward Lucas
column99: a hawkish former Moscow correspondent for The Economist
column100:
but Lucas\xa0says former Estonian president Toomas Hendrik Ilves coined the word.

\n\n

Schroeder and Putin go way back
column101: first becoming close as two alpha-male European leaders in the early 2000s. Just before the German was ejected from office after losing his 2005 re-election campaign to Merkel
column102: he gave Putin a parting gift: approval of the Kremlin’s controversial Nord Stream pipeline. The project directed Russian gas into Europe via Germany
column103: upping Moscow’s leverage over the continent. (Russia had previously relied on a route through Ukraine
column104: which was a source of various disputes between the two countries
column105: often leading to Moscow temporarily shutting off the pipeline.) Straight after his election defeat
column106: Schroeder took a well-remunerated job as chairman of the project. After its completion
column107: he became chair of its second iteration
column108: Nord Stream 2
column109:
and last year was named chairman of Russia’s state-owned oil giant Rosneft.

Bad bromance?

The two men share more than just a passion for Russian oil and gas expansion
column110:
though. They’ve long enjoyed having a good hug.

Like that time in April 2001.

And September 2001.

And November 2001.

And December 2001.

The AP and Reuters have no documented hugs in 2002. But the news organizations caught\xa0Schroeder and Putin finding each other again in October 2003.

And their wives awkwardly watching the two connect again in April 2004.

The two men found a furtive corner in July 2005.

By October 2005
column111:
they’d got that walking side-hug down.

\n\n

After Schroeder left office in November 2005
column112: the press wasn’t around as much to document any potential embraces. But in 2014
column113: just after Putin’s annexation of Crimea
column114:
the European Press Association snapped him giving Schroeder a cuddle in St Petersburg on the German’s 70th birthday. The German media wasn’t impressed.

A seaport never sleeps. Cargo shipping is vital for keeping supply chains moving and the country fed and well-supplied during the current pandemic. Port employees have continued working throughout the pandemic. They’ve not shut down like so many industries have.

Another industry that has never shut down is human trafficking. In fact

\n\n

Although it is quietly hidden
column47:
human trafficking thrives during times of chaos and vulnerability. The maritime community can benefit from an improved understanding of human trafficking and learning how employees at seaports can play a key role in helping vulnerable people.

\n\n

Victims of human trafficking include children

column49: fraud or coercion. At seaports in particular
column50: traffickers can take advantage of discrepancies in maritime law in order to exploit their victims
column51:
making a tremendous profit.

column52: crewmembers can be forced to work long hours
column53: manipulated into extending their contracts
column54: be paid less than they agreed to work for
column55:
or see their wages withheld entirely.

\n\n

It is not just labor trafficking that seaports need to watch for. Sex trafficking can happen at ports as well. Survivors of human trafficking report that sailors can be sex buyers. In these instances
column56: the sex buying can happen at port facilities or onboard docked ships. The U.S. Department of Justice Human Trafficking Task Force reports that 83 percent of U.S. sex trafficking victims are U.S. citizens
column57:
and that the average age a victim is first exploited for commercial sex is between 12-14 years old.

column59:
where they’ve asked transportation leaders to commit to helping end the practice. Signing the pledge includes committing to train employees to recognize and report the signs of human trafficking.

\n\n

prosecution and partnership—which includes key security checkpoints.

\n\n

column69:
they can learn how to spot a potential trafficking situation happening at maritime facilities and know how to report it quickly and safely. This can allow more exploited people the chance to escape their traffickers and rebuild their lives.

it can help save lives by generating more eyes and ears looking out for the warning signs of human trafficking at seaports.

column10: 'articleBody': 'Donald Trump ’s administration is considering making changes to a law that makes it illegal for American companies to bribe foreign officials in exchange for business.\n\nIn a press conference at the White House on Friday
column11: White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow told reporters the administration was “looking at” the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA).\n\n“I would just say: We are aware of it
column13: and we’ve heard complaints from some of our companies
column14: ” said Mr Kudlow in response to a question about the FCPA.\n\n“I don’t want to say anything definitive policy-wise
column15: but we are looking at it.”\n\nMr Kudlow would not go into specifics about the possible changes and told reporters to “wait until we get a better package”
column16: according to CNBC.\n\nAccording to Mr Rucker and Ms Leonnig
column17: Mr Trump expressed his unhappiness at the FCPA
column18:
calling it “unfair”.

The FCPA was established in 1977 and states it is “unlawful for certain classes or persons and entities to make payments to foreign government officials to assist in obtaining or retaining business”.

Mr Trump in 2017 reportedly told former secretary of state Rex Tillerson: “It’s just so unfair that American companies aren’t allowed to pay bribes to get business overseas.

“We’re going to change that.”

Mr Trump reportedly told Mr Tillerson to “get rid of that law”
column19: which Mr Tillerson said would be almost impossible to get Congress to do.\n\nThe president then reportedly instructed Stephen Miller
column20: a senior policy adviser
column21: to draft an executive action to repeal the FCPA.\n\nMr Trump has had a longstanding problem with the FCPA and expressed his displeasure in the past. In 2012
column22: he told CNBC is was a “horrible” law and “the world is laughing at us” for obeying it.\n\nHis disdain for the anti-corruption law appears to be at odds with one of his main defences against impeachment.'

column5: but this cheap new form of terrorism is overwhelming.

column1: The unknown source of the Indian rumors exploited recent sectarian violence in the northeastern city of Assam that have left 75 dead and 300
column2: 000 stranded in shelters. Northeastern migrants
column3: many of whom had recently moved to the south to find work

column1: The incident underscores both the accessibility of new forms of cyber-terrorism and the tricky credibility of social media.

column2: I know how powerfully credibly social media can seem. Mild panic gripped the campus in 2009 when rumors of a gunman began circulating through Facebook and SMS. UCI authorities alerted students to stay inside. Getting official reports was difficult

column4: which were much better sources of real-time information
column5: spread conflicting reports.

column3: we updated Facebook and Twitter by the second. Ultimately

column5: but that didn’t stop me and my students from fearfully hiding inside until well after the incident was over.

column1: Since Twitter and Facebook are both faster sources of information and are relaying potential first-hand accounts
column2: they’re a tempting source of credibility
column3: especially when fear leads one to err on the side of believing the more dangerous rumors.

column2: but its easy to see how this new form of terrorism
column3: combining realistic images and SMS

social services and her children\'s school.

\n\n

The second victim

said she felt she had been portrayed as ""unco-operative"" in the family court because Davey told her not to attend hearings.

She said: ""I cannot understand why he would put innocent children in danger and affect our lives so much.""

The court heard Davey sent fraudulent emails claiming to be from Warrington Borough Council and one from Merseyside Police Chief Constable Andy Cooke to back up his stories.

Tom Watson
column160: defending

accepted the victims had suffered and was remorseful.

Magistrates' court

Most criminal cases are heard in a magistrates' court. The magistrates are usually people who live in the local community
column164: sometimes called justices of the peace. There are usually three magistrates who are supported by a legally trained advisor. Sometimes cases are tried by one magistrate
column165: called a district judge
column166:
who is a lawyer.

\n\n

Magistrates\' courts are not as formal as the Crown Court
column167:
the magistrates do not wear wigs and only the ushers (court officials who keep everything running smoothly) wear black gowns.

Crown Court

Some cases are heard in the Crown Court. There are three situations where a case may be 'tried' at the Crown Court:

  1. Serious crimes
  2. Cases where the defendant (the person accused of the crime) has asked to have his case tried by a jury
  3. Magistrates may send a case to the Crown Court if they feel they do not have the power to set a sentence as severe as the crime deserves

Cases at the Crown Court are tried by a jury. These are 12 people from the general public who listen to the evidence presented during the trial and decide if the defendant is guilty of the crime. The judge decides on matters of law during the trial
column168:
such as whether certain evidence is allowed to be presented. The judge also makes sure the trial proceeds in a fair way. At the end of the trial if the defendant is found guilty the judge decides the sentence for the crime (for example how long the defendant must spend in prison).

He said because of his past offending ""the internet follows him around"".

In an email shown to the court
column169:
the defendant\'s mother said: ""He works hard and keeps trying to get on with his life but can\'t and I think it\'s unfair that he\'s unable to move on.""

\n\n

Mr Watson said Davey was studying for a degree in criminology and psychology and had been volunteering with the probation service following his release from an earlier prison sentence in 2017
column170:
but was recalled to prison for 28 days in November last year.

Detective Constable Laura Gilbert said: ""Stephen Davey is a manipulative and despicable individual who has knowingly preyed on extremely vulnerable victims.

""He is a career criminal whose only motivation throughout was to extort as much money as he could from his victims.""

Davey pleaded guilty to two counts of fraud by false representation

column1: 66	Canberk	Western Union	Company	https://techcrunch.com/2019/04/04/western-union-often-disrupted-by-startups-partners-a-startup-for-digital-push-in-the-philippines/	"Global money mover Western Union is commonly a target for fintech companies
column2: but the firm is teaming up with a startup to help increase its presence in the world’s third-most lucrative remittance market: the Philippines.

column1: Coins
column2: the Manila-based fintech startup that was recently acquired by $10 billion ride-hailing company Go-Jek
column3: said today that it will integrate Western Union
column4: which is valued at $8 billion on the NYSE
column5: into its app to allow Philippines-based users to receive money sent to them from overseas.

column1: The Philippines is a mighty country when it comes to money transfers. There are some 10 million Philippine nationals based overseas and a recent World Bank report ranked the company the world’s third-most lucrative corridor with an estimated $34 billion sent home from overseas last year. (That’s the same as Mexico
column2: with India and China in first and second place
column3: respectively.)

column1: The partnership means Coins users — the company claims five million downloads to date — who receive money via Western Union won’t need to trudge out and wait in line to collect it. Instead
column2: it can be remitted to the Coins app
column3: from where it can be transferred on to other people (peer-to-peer transfers are free) or used on the Coins platform for other payments. Money in the app can be used to pay for utility bills
column4: mobile top-up
column5: public transport trips and at merchants that support its payment service.

column1: One thing the alliance doesn’t do
column2: however
column3: is remove Western Union fees
column4: but Coins founder and CEO Ron Hose is optimistic that the deal brings value for both parties and consumers in the Philippines.

column1: “Our mission is working with banks and financial service providers to bring services to people who don’t have access
column2: ” he told TechCrunch in an interview.

column1: Hose declined to comment on Western Union payments — which are routinely seized upon by startups that look to offer more transparent and cheaper overseas transfers — but
column2: in theory
column3: moving money digitally could pave the way for retail-based remitters
column4: like Western Union
column5: to reduce operational costs and potentially make their service cheaper for consumers in the future.

column1: Western Union already operates its own apps
column2: but
column3: like a number of “old school” global money platforms
column4: its business is inherently a retail one rather than a tech one. That’s because it has a strong physical presence — with more than 500
column5: 000 location worldwide and some 12
column6: 000 in the Philippines alone — which brings with it operational costs
column7: while there is also KYC and other anti-laundering processes that increase expenditure.

column1: It remains to be seen where the Coins-Western Union deal will head. Parent company Go-Jek is busily expanding into Vietnam
column2: Thailand and Singapore while it has a strong base in its native Indonesia
column3: so there could be potential for further alliances in the future.

Published
3 April 2014

The European Parliament has urged EU governments to impose sanctions on 32 Russian officials over the death of a lawyer

column44: in force since 2012

column46:

But instead of prosecuting any of the alleged embezzlers
column47:
the police arrested Magnitsky.

Frosty relations

The MEPs\' resolution comes amid heightened tensions between the EU and Russia over Moscow\'s annexation of Crimea. The EU and US have imposed visa bans and asset freezes on senior Russian officials considered to be linked to the annexation.

Various politicians in Europe have urged their governments to adopt a US-style Magnitsky list. Last year the Irish parliament dropped plans for such a blacklist after Russia warned that it might stop adoptions by Irish parents in retaliation.

Many of the names on the proposed European Magnitsky list are also among the 18 named in the US list

The MEPs' resolution comes amid heightened tensions between the EU and Russia over Moscow's annexation of Crimea. The EU and US have imposed visa bans and asset freezes on senior Russian officials considered to be linked to the annexation.

Various politicians in Europe have urged their governments to adopt a US-style Magnitsky list. Last year the Irish parliament dropped plans for such a blacklist after Russia warned that it might stop adoptions by Irish parents in retaliation.

Many of the names on the proposed European Magnitsky list are also among the 18 named in the US list

column59:
and judge Yelena Stashina.

column60: which had ""cast doubt on the independence and impartiality of its judicial institutions
column61:
and serve as a reminder of the many documented shortcomings in respect for the rule of law in Russia"".
